capitalization per [[MOS:CAPS]]; added links & fixed dead links; moved sections; removed promotional language & peacock terms: [[WP:PROMO]], [[WP:PEACOCK]]
revision.text:
The '''Dancing Star Foundation''' is a U.S.-based [[non-profit organization]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Exempt Organizations Select Check: Dancing Star Foundation |url=https://apps.irs.gov/app/eos/pub78Search.do?ein1=77-0343380&dispatchMethod=searchCharities |website=irs.gov |publisher=U.S. [[Internal Revenue Service]] |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Dancing Star Foundation – GuideStar Profile |url=https://www.guidestar.org/profile/77-0343380 |website=guidestar.org |publisher=[[GuideStar]] |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Charity Navigator – Unrated Profile for Dancing Star Foundation |url=https://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.profile&ein=770343380 |website=charitynavigator.org |publisher=[[Charity Navigator]] |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref> engaged in environmental, cultural and [[animal welfare]] activities, including environmental education, global [[biodiversity]] [[Conservation biology|conservation]], and [[animal rights]].<ref>{{cite book |chapter=Organizations: Dancing Star Foundation (DSF) |editor1-last=Chumakov |editor1-first=Alexander Nikolaevich |editor2-last=Ilyin |editor2-first=Ilya Vyacheslavovich |editor3-last=Mazour |editor3-first=Ivan Ivanovich |date=2018 |title=Global studies directory: people, organizations, publications |series=Value inquiry book series |volume=302 |location=Leiden; Boston |publisher=[[Brill Publishers|Brill Rodopi]] |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=tDE9DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA398 398–399] |isbn=9789004348479 |oclc=994296658 |doi=10.1163/9789004353855}}</ref> It was founded in 1993.<ref name="Mission">{{cite web |title=About the Foundation – Mission |url=http://www.dancingstarfoundation.org/mission.php |website=dancingstarfoundation.org |publisher=Dancing Star Foundation |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref>
==Areas of focus==
===Education===
Via print and film, Dancing Star Foundation seeks to increase awareness of environmental issues ranging from biodiversity and [[extinction]] to [[non-violence]] and [[over-population]].<ref name="Mission"/> Examples are ''No Vacancy'', a book and documentary film combination which addresses the volatile issue of population stabilization in the U.S., China, and eight other countries; the book ''Sanctuary'', "a 338-page compendium of full color photography showcasing twenty-four animal sanctuaries located throughout twenty different countries";<ref>{{cite web |title=Book review: Sanctuary: Global Oases Of Innocence |publisher=[[Midwest Book Review]] |date=2008 |url=http://www.sanctuary-thebook.org/news/news.html |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref> and the documentary film ''Mad Cowboy'', the story of cattle rancher-turned-[[vegan]] and animal rights activist [[Howard Lyman]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Richards |first=Jennie |date=1 March 2016 |title=Documentary film ''Mad Cowboy'', the story of Howard Lyman |url=http://www.humanedecisions.com/documentary-film-mad-cowboy-the-story-of-howard-lyman/ |website=humanedecisions.com |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref>
===Animal protection===
The foundation operates an animal sanctuary in [[Central California]] for rescued animals.<ref name="Sanctuary">{{cite web |title=Animal Protection – U.S. Sanctuaries |url=http://www.dancingstarfoundation.org/mission.php |website=dancingstarfoundation.org |publisher=Dancing Star Foundation |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref> The mission of the facilities is to provide sanctuary "for the benefit, solace, peace and quiet of the resident species".<ref name="Sanctuary"/>
===Biodiversity conservation===
The foundation is involved in efforts to promote biodiversity conservation—mostly through "documentation in book and film form of research being carried out by governments, other NGOs and individual ecologists"—in various countries.<ref>{{cite web |title=Biodiversity Conservation |url=http://www.dancingstarfoundation.org/biodiversity_conservation.php |website=dancingstarfoundation.org |publisher=Dancing Star Foundation |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref>
===UCLA medical school===
Dancing Star Foundation created and funded an alternative [[oncology]] program, the Sue Stiles Program in Integrative Oncology at the [[Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center]] in 2001.<ref name="Stiles Program">{{cite web |title=Stiles Program in Integrative Oncology |url=https://ccim.med.ucla.edu/?page_id=158 |website=ccim.med.ucla.edu |publisher=[[UCLA School of Medicine]] |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref> The program is under the direction of oncologist Richard J. Pietras.<ref name="Stiles Program"/>
==Current leadership==
===President===
Michael Tobias is president of the foundation.<ref name="Biographies">{{cite web |title=About the Foundation – Biographies |url=http://www.dancingstarfoundation.org/bios.html |website=dancingstarfoundation.org |publisher=Dancing Star Foundation |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref> His academic resume includes a Ph.D. in [[History of Consciousness]] from [[UC Santa Cruz]], an Assistant Professorship in [[Environmental Studies]], and Adjunct Assistant Professor of English and the Humanities, Visiting Garrey Carruthers Chair of Honors at the [[University of New Mexico]], Distinguished Visiting Professor and Regents Lecturer at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]], and an Associate Professorship at [[Cal State Northridge]].<ref name="Biographies"/> He is "the author of 37 books and writer/director/producer of over 100 films pertaining to environmental, cultural, social or scientific issues".<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite news |last=Oosthuizen |first=François |date=2008 |title=The race against extinction |newspaper=2Magazine |location=Bangkok, Thailand |url=http://www.hotspots-thefilm.org/media/assets/2featureHOTSPOTS.pdf |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref>
===Executive vice president===
Jane Gray Morrison is executive vice president of the foundation.<ref name="Biographies"/> An ecologist/filmmaker, Morrison produced the ten-hour [[Turner Broadcasting]] series "Voice of the Planet", which chronicled the history of life on Earth; the project "involved filming for nearly two years in 25 countries".<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Morrison is also responsible for the production of a trilogy of [[documentary film]]s titled "Mad Cowboy", "No Vacancy", and "Hotspots", and has co-authored books on [[environmental issues]].<ref name="Biographies"/>
===Vice president, finance and operations===
Don Cannon is vice president of finance and operations of the foundation.<ref name="Biographies"/> Cannon's background includes tenures with both [[A&M Records]] and [[Elektra Records]], as well as [[Hanna Barbera]] and other [[television production]] companies.<ref name="Biographies"/> Prior to joining Dancing Star Foundation, he was a senior vice president at [[ICM Partners]], a large talent management agency.<ref name="Biographies"/>
==Euthanasia controversy==
In early 2009, a small number of former employees alleged that the Cayucos animal sanctuary was [[Animal euthanasia|euthanizing animals]] for economic reasons.<ref name=LAT260209>{{cite news |last=Chawkins |first=Steve |date=26 February 2009 |title=Animal sanctuaries criticized over surge in euthanizations |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/feb/26/local/me-animal-sanctuary26 |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref><ref name=CBS200209>{{cite web |title=Ex-employees claim CA sanctuary killing animals |date=20 February 2009 |publisher=CBS 5 News |url=http://cbs5.com/local/animals.horses.Euthanized.2.940213.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228135350/http://cbs5.com/local/animals.horses.Euthanized.2.940213.html |archivedate=28 February 2009 |accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref> A maintenance supervisor who made similar allegations claims he was dismissed due to speaking out, although the sanctuary says he was terminated for other reasons.<ref>{{cite news |last=Tanner |first=Kathe |date=19 February 2009 |title=Sanctuary is euthanizing animals to save money, ex-workers say; officials at Dancing Star shelter on north coast say actions are justified for health reasons |newspaper=[[The Tribune (San Luis Obispo)]] |url=http://www.sanluisobispo.com/news/local/breaking_news/story/631514.html}}{{dead link|date=February 2017}}</ref> Dancing Star denied the animal-care allegations, saying that they are "contrary to our most deeply held beliefs" and that the Foundation is "unwavering in our commitment to compassion".<ref name=CBS200209/> [[San Luis Obispo County]] Animal Services determined that the euthanized animals were "either beyond treatment or had conditions for which euthanasia would be at least one of the considerations that could be responsibly made".<ref name="LAT260209"/> The general counsel of the [[Farm Sanctuary]] in New York State, who examined the Cayucos sanctuary following the allegations, said he was unable to confirm the process for selecting those who had been euthanized.<ref name=LAT260209/> But he noted, "It's the best-funded place in the country for animals, and the staff appears to be caring."<ref name=LAT260209/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|www.dancingstarfoundation.org}}
[[Category:International environmental organizations]] [[Category:Animal charities based in the United States]] [[Category:Charities based in California]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Greek Dimos |name = Gavdos |name_local = Γαύδος |image_map = 2011 Dimos Gavdou.png |periph = [[Crete]] |periphunit = [[Chania (regional unit)|Chania]] |pop_municipality = 152 |area_municipality = 32.4 |population_as_of = 2011 |elevation_min = 0 |elevation_max = 345 |coordinates = {{coord|34|50|N|24|05|E|format=dms|display=inline,title}} |postal_code = 730 01 |area_code = 28230 |licence = ΧΝ |mayor = |website = |image_skyline = Gavdos.jpg |caption_skyline = Gavdos island satellite image. |party = |since = }} '''Gavdos''' ({{lang-el|Γαύδος}}, {{IPA-el|ˈɣavðos|}}) is the southernmost [[List of islands of Greece|Greek island]], located to the south of its much larger neighbour, [[Crete]], of which it is administratively a part, in the regional unit of [[Chania (regional unit)|Chania]]. It forms a community with surrounding islets and was part of the former [[Selino Province]]. The island is situated at the southern tip of Greece, thus making it the [[Extreme points of Europe|southernmost]] point of the entire [[Europe|European continent]].
==Name== Gavdos has been known by a wide variety of names. For example, it appears in the biblical account of [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]]'s journey to Rome in [[Acts 27]] as "Clauda" ({{lang|grc|Κλαῦδα}}) or "Cauda" ({{lang|grc|Καῦδα}}). The island was also referred to as "Cauda" by Roman geographer [[Pomponius Mela]], and as "Gaudos" by [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]]. [[Ptolemy]] called Gavdos "Claudos" ({{lang|grc|Κλαῦδος}}).<ref>[http://bible.cc/acts/27-16.htm Acts 27:16], Biblos.com parallel bible</ref> The [[Republic of Venice|Venetian]]s called it "Gotzo", perhaps in imitation of the [[Malta|Maltese]] island "[[Gozo]]".<ref>[http://www.kreta2005.nl/uk/gavdos.html ''The island of Gavdos''], [http://www.kreta2005.nl/uk/index.html Crete Travel Guide]</ref> From the 17th to the 19th centuries, the island was known as "Gondzo". A [[Turkish language|Turkish]] name of Godzo was "Bougadoz".
[[File:Kap Tripiti.jpg|thumb|250px|left|<center>Kap Trypiti, the most southern point of Europe. The sculpture of the oversized chair can be seen.</center>]]
==Geography== The island is {{convert|26|nmi|km|0}} south of [[Chora Sfakion]]. The area of the municipality, which includes the small island [[Gavdopoula]], is {{convert|32.424|km2|1|abbr=out}}.<ref name=stat01>{{cite web |url=http://dlib.statistics.gr/Book/GRESYE_02_0101_00098%20.pdf |publisher=National Statistical Service of Greece |title=Population & housing census 2001 (incl. area and average elevation) |language=el |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150921212047/http://dlib.statistics.gr/Book/GRESYE_02_0101_00098%20.pdf |archivedate=2015-09-21 |df= }}</ref> The island is roughly triangular in shape. Its highest point is Mount Vardia, {{convert|345|m|0|abbr=off}}. The southeastern corner is a rocky peninsula with a [[natural arch]] carved by the elements, called Trypiti. A sculpture of an oversized chair sits on top of Trypiti.
There is an islet called [[Gavdopoula]] (Γαυδοπούλα, "little Gavdos") to the north west of Gavdos. Gavdos and Gavdopoula are covered with [[garrigue|phrygana]] (φρύγανα), low-lying shrubs. Both are important stops for [[bird migration|migrating]] birds.<ref>[http://www.gavdos-online.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=14&Itemid=17 ''European populations of migratory birds''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711075804/http://www.gavdos-online.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=14&Itemid=17 |date=2011-07-11 }}, ''Natural History Museum of Crete'' of the [[University of Crete]], Flora and Fauna on Gavdos, [http://www.gavdos-online.com/index.php?option=com_frontpage&Itemid=1 Gavdos Online Service] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100310053956/http://www.gavdos-online.com/index.php?option=com_frontpage&Itemid=1 |date=2010-03-10 }}, March 1, 2008.</ref> Local birds include the [[Eurasian scops-owl|Eurasian scops owl]] and the [[European shag]]. Gavdos also has a variety of other vegetation, such as [[Maquis shrubland|maquis]] as well as forests of [[pine]]s and [[junipers]].<ref>[http://www.ornithologiki.gr/en/sppe/en181.php ''GR181 Gavdos and Gavdopoula islands''], Important Areas for the Birds of Greece, [[Hellenic Ornithological Society]], 2007</ref>
[[File:Gavdos, potamos beach from Ambellos path.jpg|thumb|250px|left|<center>Potamos-beach on Gavdos with the island of Crete in the background.</center>]]
===Climate=== Gavdos is the southernmost island in [[Greece]] and all of [[Europe]], with a [[Mediterranean climate|warm Mediterranean subtropical climate]] typical of the [[List of islands of Greece|Greek islands]] (Csa for [[Köppen climate classification|Koppen Classification]]), summers are constantly hot with daily temperatures reaching 32 ° C in August (extremes are occasional, sometimes it can reach 40 ° C) and extremely mild winters by European standards, February, the coldest month has an average temperature of 17 ° C. The [[Mediterranean Sea]] is an important thermal regulator that surrounds it island in all its directions, while maintaining the high temperature of the sea, especially in summer passing from 26 ° C. The mild climate is aided by hot winds blowing from the [[Sahara|Sahara Desert]]. The countless mountains of the [[Balkans]] protect from the cold, siberian air, in addition to its island condition. As a result of the [[Subtropical High]] of the [[Azores]] precipitation is concentrated in winter, making summer dry with almost none used as "beach time". It is the sunniest place in [[Europe]] and with the highest number of [[radiation]]: between 1800 and 1900 kWh/m² (ideal for [[Solar panel|solar panels]]), valoers closer to [[North Africa]] and the [[Middle East|Middle East.]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.touristmaker.com/greece/gavdos/|title=Gavdos, Greece|work=Tourist Maker|access-date=2018-08-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hotspotenergy.com/DC-air-conditioner/europe-solar-hours.php|title=Solar Sun Hours {{!}} Average Daily Solar Insolation {{!}} Europe|website=www.hotspotenergy.com|access-date=2018-08-29}}</ref>{{Weather box |location = Gavdos, Greece |metric first = Yes |single line = Y |Jan high F = 57.4 |Feb high F = 58.1 |Mar high F = 61.2 |Apr high F = 68.0 |May high F = 76.3 |Jun high F = 84.4 |Jul high F = 87.1 |Aug high F = 86.0 |Sep high F = 81.5 |Oct high F = 73.4 |Nov high F = 66.4 |Dec high F = 60.3 |year high F= 71.7 |Jan low F = 46.2 |Feb low F = 46.0 |Mar low F = 47.7 |Apr low F = 52.7 |May low F = 59.0 |Jun low F = 66.2 |Jul low F = 70.2 |Aug low F = 70.0 |Sep low F = 66.0 |Oct low F = 60.3 |Nov low F = 54.0 |Dec low F = 49.1 |year low F= 57.3 |source 1 = <yr.no= >{{cite web |url=https://www.yr.no/place/Greece/Crete/Gavdos/statistics.html | publisher=YR.no |year=2016 |work=Weather statistics for Gavdos, Crete (Greece) |accessdate=12 September 2016}} |date= |title=Weather statistics for Gavdos}}
==Demographics== There are only a small number of year-round residents of Gavdos and services for tourists are basic. {{As of|2011}}, the total population of Gavdos was measured as 152 people.<ref name=census11/> In reality, fewer than 50 people live permanently on the island. In the summer the total people on the island can reach over 3,500, most of whom are campers and tourists. The largest man-made harbour for [[ferry|ferries]] is Karave. The [[List of islands of Greece|island's]] capital is Kastri. The southernmost populated village is [[Vatsiana]], with a total permanent population of 31 people.
==History== Gavdos has supported a permanent population since [[Neolithic]] times. However, the island currently has very few permanent residents.
Gavdos has been identified as a possible site of the mythical [[Ogygia]] where [[Calypso (mythology)|Kalypso]] held [[Odysseus]] prisoner. Archaeological evidence showed that the [[Roman empire]] was active on the island. During that time the [[flora (plants)|flora]] of the island was [[overexploited]] and that started a process of [[erosion]] which has continued to this day.
Gavdos had approximately 8,000 inhabitants by 900 AD. During the [[Ottoman Empire]]'s reign on the island, which lasted from 1665 until 1895, Gavdos was known as Gondzo. During this period the population decreased considerably to only 500 by 1882. A reference to [[Saracens]] on the island survives: the [[beach]] Sarakiniko ("''of the Saracens''").
In the 1930s the island was used as a place of exile of [[communist]]s; more than 250 people were [[exile]]d including leading figures of the Greek movement, such as [[Markos Vafiadis]]. During World War II, allied forces evacuated some forces to Gavdos following the German victory in the [[battle of Crete]].<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Nazis Pound Crete Allies | date=June 1, 1941 | publisher= | url =https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/411267591.html?dids=411267591:411267591&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&date=Jun+01%2C+1941&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Nazis+Pound+Crete+Allies&pqatl=google | work =Los Angeles Times | pages = | accessdate = 2007-09-27 | language = }}</ref>
Later on, the general phase of [[urbanization]] that started in other parts of Greece in the 1960s took place in the 1950s on Gavdos. During that period the islanders exchanged their land on Gavdos with ex-Turkish land on Crete, which had now become exchangeable via the state.<ref>?</ref> Upon settling in Crete they created a community known as Gavdiotika, which is part of the town of [[Paleochora]].
==Economy== There are many abandoned terraces on Gavdos where farmers used to grow crops on the hillsides. There still is some agriculture on Gavdos. During the summer, the population of the island swells to a few thousand because of tourists, although there are few facilities for tourists. There is one year-round cafe in Carave (''Karabe'') on Gavdos run by Evangelina Tsigonakis.<ref name=Pickford/> There is a modern non-functioning reproduction lighthouse tower on Gavdos which now serves as a cafe during the summer season; the complex also contains a museum on the history of the original lighthouse with several rooms of photos and antique equipment. Gavdos has an [[FM radio]] station, ''Gavdos FM 88.8'', which is also available online.<ref>[http://www.gavdosfm.gr/ Gavdosfm homepage]</ref>
==Politics== Following years of isolation, in 1996 the island came to [[Mass media|media]] prominence. In a [[NATO]] exercise Gavdos was the focal point of a confrontation between Greece and [[Turkey]]. Following that, [[Prime Minister of Greece|Prime Minister]] [[Costas Simitis]] visited Gavdos and announced a five-year, [[euro|€]]1.5 million plan for the island's development.
In 2001, [[Costis Stephanopoulos]], the Greek President, inaugurated a [[telemedicine]] centre on Gavdos, an island which has not had a full-time [[Physician|doctor]] in recent memory. This effort, however, was marred as the island's [[infrastructure]] could not provide the necessary [[Electrical power|power]] required by the centre. For the purposes of the inauguration, [[Electricity generation|generators]] were brought in, which were then removed. However, according to a 2008 [[BBC News]] report the island now features stable electrical power, and young medical graduates can serve for six months on Gavdos in lieu of [[Conscription in Greece|compulsory military service]]. But visitors to Gavdos in June 2008 found that the power station was not functioning and that businesses were relying on gas generators operated for a few hours per night; locals stated that the power station worked initially, but no longer serves the entire island reliably.<ref name=Pickford/>
In 2002, the island was in the news again, due to the arrests of members of the extremist [[Marxist]] group [[Revolutionary Organization 17 November|17 November]]. The leader of this organization had been living openly for several years on Gavdos as a [[beekeeper]].<ref name=Pickford>[http://newsvote.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/7205519.stm ''The Med's 'forgotten' island: It is hard to imagine a more spectacular edge of a continent''], John Pickford, [[BBC News]], January 24, 2008.</ref>
==Gavdos in Literature== Gavdos is featured in [[James Aldridge]]'s 1944 novel ''The Sea Eagle'', which tells the story of the escape of a Greek partisan and two Australian soldiers after the [[Battle of Crete]]. The three join an expedition to liberate some Cretan fishermen from a [[Metaxas Regime|Metaxas-era]] prison on the eastern end of the island. The attack on the cliffs of Khavro Spahti Bay is described in Chapters 24-28.
==See also== *[[List of communities of Chania]] *[[List of islands of Greece]] *[[Levantine Sea#Geography|Geography of the Levantine Sea]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.gavdosisland.gr/ Gavdos portal - travel guide] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070329050218/http://www.unterwasserwelt-history.de/html/insel_gavdos.html Gavdos harbour-Story] {{de icon}} *[http://newsvote.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/7205519.stm The Med's 'forgotten' island (BBC)] {{en icon}}

[[File:Geghama Mountains.jpg|thumb|Geghama mountains]] [[File:Cave City Tegh.jpg|thumb|Caves of [[Tegh]], [[Armenia]] ("Cave City")]] [[Image:Armenia Topography.png|thumb|Topography of Armenia]] [[File:2014 Prowincja Kotajk, Garni, Wąwóz Garni (28).jpg|thumb|[[Garni Gorge]]]] [[File:Garni Gorge Armenia (24).JPG|thumb|[[Columnar jointing]] at [[Garni Gorge]]]] [[File:Medny-kolchedan.jpg|thumb|[[Chalcopyrite]] ore from the deposit at [[Shamlugh]] in Armenia. From the collection of the [[Vernadsky State Geological Museum]] in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]]] [[File:Gutanasar. Mount of Armenia 2. Lava.JPG|thumb|Lava in Gutanasar mountain range]] [[File:Old Goris.jpeg|thumb|"Old [[Goris]]" rock formation in Armenia]]
The '''geology of Armenia''' was shaped by geological upheaval pushed up the [[Earth's crust]] to form the [[Armenian Plateau]] 25 million years ago. This created the complex [[topography]] of Armenia.
The [[Lesser Caucasus]] range extends through northern Armenia, runs southeast between [[Lake Sevan]] and Azerbaijan, then passes roughly along the Armenian-Azerbaijani border to Iran. Thus situated, the mountains make travel from north to south difficult.
==Earthquakes== Geological turmoil continues in the form of devastating earthquakes. In December 1988, the second largest city in the republic, [[Gyumri]] (then called Leninakan), was heavily damaged by a massive quake that killed more than 25,000 people.
==Terrain== About half of Armenia's area of approximately {{convert|29,800|km2|sqmi|1|abbr=on}} has an elevation of at least {{convert|2000|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, and only 3% of the country lies below {{convert|650|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}. The lowest points are in the valleys of the Araks River and the Debet River in the far north, which have elevations of {{convert|380|and|430|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, respectively. Elevations in the Lesser Caucasus vary between {{convert|2640|and|3280|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}. To the southwest of the range is the Armenian Plateau, which slopes southwestward toward the Araks River on the Turkish border. The plateau is masked by intermediate mountain ranges and extinct volcanoes. The largest of these, [[Mount Aragats]], {{convert|4095|m|ft|0|sp=us}} high, is also the highest point in Armenia. Most of the population lives in the western and northwestern parts of the country, where the two major cities, [[Yerevan]] and Gyumri (which was called Aleksandropol' during the tsarist period), are located.
The valleys of the [[Debet River]] and [[Akstafa River]] as they pass through mountain areas form the chief routes into Armenia from the north. [[Lake Sevan]] is by far the largest lake at {{convert|72.5|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} across at its widest point and {{convert|376|km|mi|1|abbr=on}} long. It lies {{convert|2070|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} above sea level on the plateau.
Armenia's terrain is most rugged in the extreme southeast, which is drained by the [[Bargushat River]] and most moderate in the [[Araks River]] valley to the extreme southwest. Most of Armenia is drained by the [[Araks]] or its tributary, the [[Hrazdan]], which flow from Lake Sevan. The Araks forms most of Armenia's border with [[Turkey]] and [[Iran]] while the [[Zangezur Mountains]] form the border between Armenia's southern [[Syunik Province|province of Syunik]] and Azerbaijan's adjacent Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic. [[Image:Armenian terrain.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Armenian terrain]]
===Volcanic mountains=== Volcanic mountains in Armenia include [[Mount Ara]], [[Mount Aragats]], [[Azhdahak]], [[Ghegam Ridge]], [[Mount of Armenia]]. [[Porak]]. [[Arpi Gorge]] and [[Garni Gorge]] contain columnar igneous rocks ([[Columnar jointing]]).
==Mining== Mines in Armenia include [[Kajaran Mine]] and [[Teghut Mine]]. Both are [[open pit mine]]s for [[copper]] and [[molybdenum]].
==Fossils== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 65%;" |- ! Group or Formation ! Period ! class="unsortable"| Notes |- | [[Akhura Formation]] || [[Permian]] || |- | [[Ali Bashi Formation]] || [[Permian]] || |- | [[Arpinskaya Formation]] || [[Permian]] || |- | [[Dzhulfa Formation]] || [[Permian]] || |- | [[Gnishik Formation]] || [[Permian]] || |- | [[Gundara Formation]] || [[Permian]] || |- | [[Julfa Formation]] || [[Permian]] || |- | [[Karabaglyar Formation]] || [[Triassic]] || |- | [[Khachik Formation]] || [[Permian]] || |- |} <ref>{{cite web|title= Fossilworks: Gateway to the Paleobiology Database|author= Various Contributors to the Paleobiology Database|url= http://www.fossilworks.org/|accessdate= 8 July 2014|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140731140924/http://fossilworks.org/|archivedate= 31 July 2014|df= }}</ref>
==References== {{commonscat}} {{Reflist}} * {{loc}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox protected area | name = Ivvavik National Park
''Parc national Ivvavik'' ([[Canadian French|French]]) | iucn_category = II | photo = File:Sheep Slot Rapids, Firth River, Ivvavik National Park, YT.jpg | photo_caption = Sheep Slot Rapids on the Firth River | map = Canada | relief = yes | map_width = 260 | map_caption = Location of ''Ivvavik National Park'' in [[Canada]] | location = [[Yukon]], Canada | nearest_city = [[Inuvik, Northwest Territories|Inuvik]] | coordinates = {{coord|69|31|11|N|139|31|30|W|display=inline, title}} | area_km2 = 10168 | established = 1984 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [[Parks Canada]] }} '''Ivvavik National Park''' is located in [[Yukon]], Canada. Initially named "Northern Yukon National Park," the park was renamed Ivvavik in 1992 for the [[Inuvialuktun]] word meaning "nursery" or "birthplace,"{{Cite news|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/ivvavik-national-park/|title=Ivvavik National Park|last=Finkelstein|first=Maxwell W.|newspaper=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]]|access-date=2016-12-01}} in reference to the importance of the area as a calving ground for caribou.2018 - Park Management - Ivvavik National Park {{ISBN|978-0-660-23910-1}} Created as a result of the [[Inuvialuit Final Agreement]] in 1984, negotiated between the [[Government of Canada|Canadian Government]] and the [[Inuvialuit]] of the Northern Yukon, Ivvavik is the first national park in Canada to be established as a result of an aboriginal land claims agreement.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/pn-np/yt/ivvavik/index.aspx|title=Parks Canada - Ivvavik National Park|last=Canada|first=Parks Canada Agency, Government of|website=www.pc.gc.ca|access-date=2016-12-01}} Ivvavik contains the [[British Mountains]] which run east to west, parallel to the Arctic coast, and merge into the [[Brooks Range]] in Alaska. Draining north through the Park from the British Mountains is the [[Firth River]], the oldest river in Canadahttp://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/yt/ivvavik/info and considered one of the great rafting rivers of the world. The river starts from year-round [[aufeis]] formations at the headwaters and then flows through extensive canyon areas before forming a huge delta as it enters the [[Beaufort Sea]] just west of [[Herschel Island]]. The first raft descent was by Martyn Williams, Alan Dennis and Jim Boyde. Gold miners have operated on the Firth River and at Sheep Creek until the area became a National Park. The area around Sheep Creek is the northern most extension of Dall sheep habitat in Canada The park contains many cultural sites of continuing importance to the local indigenous people, both Inuit and Indian. Protecting a portion of the calving grounds of the [[Porcupine caribou]] herd, the park allows only a minimal number of people to visit per year. On the shore of Beaufort Sea, there is abundant game for [[Northwestern wolf|timber wolves]], [[grizzly bear]]s, and [[American black bear|black bear]]s that inhabit the area. Other animals that inhabit this park two species of [[fox]], [[Alaska moose|moose]], [[lemming]]s, [[Dall sheep]], [[gyrfalcon]]s, [[muskox]]en, and [[wolverine]]s. The [[Arctic National Wildlife Refuge]] lies just across the border in [[Alaska]]. The [[Firth River]] holds some of the longest stocks of [[Arctic char|Dolly Varden char]] in western Canada On the south-east, Ivvavik National Park borders [[Vuntut National Park]], established in 1995. Due to land claims negotiations, Vuntut is still quite undeveloped and has no roads or developed trails. Due to its undeveloped nature, several people have got lost and are presumed dead.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} ==See also== {{portal|Arctic|Geography of Canada|Yukon}} *[[National Parks of Canada]] *[[List of National Parks of Canada]] *[[List of Yukon parks]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Ivvavik National Park}} {{wikivoyage|Ivvavik National Park}} *[http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/pn-np/yt/ivvavik/index.aspx Official site] {{National parks of Canada}} {{World Heritage Sites in Canada}} {{Yukon parks}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:National parks in Yukon]] [[Category:Protected areas of the Arctic]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 1984]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox ancient site | name = Kamyana Mohyla | native_name = | alternate_name = <!-- image & map --> | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_type = | map_caption = | map_size = | coordinates = {{coord|46|57|0|N|35|28|12|E|scale:100000|display=inline,title}} | location = Melitopol, Melitopol Raion, [[Zaporizhia Oblast]], [[Ukraine]] | type = National Archeological Site | part_of = <!-- stats --> | altitude_m = | length = | width = | area = | volume = | diameter = | circumference = | height = | builder = | material = | built = | abandoned = | epochs = <!-- actually displays as 'Periods' --> | cultures = | dependency_of = | occupants = | event = | discovered = | excavations = | archaeologists = | condition = | ownership = | management = | public_access = | website = [http://www.stonegrave.org/ www.stonegrave.org] | notes = <!-- Other --> | other_designation = }} {{distinguish|Stone Tombs Natural Reserve}} [[File:Музей (Каменная могила).jpg|thumb|]] [[File:Музей, экспозиции (Каменная могила).jpg|thumb|]] [[File:Камяна могила схема.jpg|thumb|The site schematics]] '''Kamyana Mohyla''' ({{lang-uk|Кам'яна Могила}}; literally: "stone tomb") is an archaeological site in the [[Molochna River]] (literally "Milk river") valley, about a mile from the village of Terpinnya, [[Zaporizhia Oblast]], Ukraine. Petroglyphs of Kamyana Mohyla are dated from Upper Paleolithic (Kukrek culture) to Medieval, with Stone Age depictions subjected to most archaeological interest. [[File:Каменная Могила, панорама 3. Автор Максим Стоялов.jpg|thumb|]] The site encompasses a group of isolated blocks of [[sandstone]], up to twelve meters in height, scattered around an area of some 3,000 square meters. As [[Noghai]] legend has it, it resulted from a scuffle of two [[baghatur]]s who took turns throwing rocks at each other. In truth, the site had its origins in a [[sandbank]] of the [[Tethys Ocean]]. For a long time it was an island in the Molochna River, which has since been silted up and now flows a short distance to the west. It is thought to represent the only sandstone outcrop in the [[Azov-Kuban Depression]].
The shape of this sand hill is similar to that of [[kurgan]]s that dot the [[Pontic-Caspian steppe]]. In 1889, the Russian archaeologist [[Nikolay Veselovsky]] was called upon to explore the enigmatic site and started excavations the following year. As soon as he concluded that the site was a burial mound, excavations were terminated. There was very little scientific exploration of the site during the first third of the 20th century.
In the 1930s the site was investigated by a team of scholars from [[Melitopol]] under [[Valentin Danylenko]] (1913–82). The young archaeologist claimed to have discovered thirty caves with [[petroglyph]] inscriptions which he dated from the 20th century BC to the 17th century AD. Danylenko resumed his work on the site after [[World War II]] and claimed to have discovered thirteen additional caves with petroglyphs. [[Image:Kamenna2.jpg|thumb|left|150px|A stone with petroglyphs.]] The site was designated an archaeological preserve in 1954. The move was intended to prevent the area from being flooded after construction of a [[water reservoir]]. During the following decades, the condition of petroglyphs visibly deteriorated.
Petroglyphs are found only inside the caves and grottoes of Kamenna Mohyla, many of them still filled up with sand. No adequate protection from the elements has been provided to this day. No traces of ancient human settlement have been discovered in the vicinity, leading many scholars to believe that the hill served as a remote [[sanctuary]]. Faint traces of red paint remain on parts of the surface. Scholars have been unable to agree whether the petroglyphs date from [[Mesolithic]] or [[Neolithic]]. The latter dating is more popular, although the presumed depiction of a [[mammoth]] in one of the caves seems to favour the former date.{{Fact|date=November 2008}}
In 2006, the government of Ukraine nominated the site for inscription on the [[World Heritage List]]. On the whole, the Stone Tomb images represent traces of religious exercises of the hunters and cattle-breeders of this steppe zone of southeast Europe from the 20th century BC to the 17th century AD. Some caves are of artificial origin; their cultural strata have been fixed as the Neolithic, Bronze and Early Iron Ages as well as of Middle Ages.[http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5075/]
Danylenko's magnum opus about the site was released posthumously, but it took the publication of [[Anatoly Kifishin]]'s hefty monograph in 2001 to attract wider attention to Kamenna Mohyla. In this controversial work, Kifishin compared the petroglyphs of Kamenna Mohyla to those of [[Çatalhöyük]] and concluded that both were related to the [[Sumer]]ian [[cuneiform script]]. Shortly before his death, [[Igor Diakonov]] lashed out against Kifishin's hypothesis (the two openly feuded since the 1960s).

'''Kelvyn Jones''', {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|FBA|FAcSS|FLSW}} (born {{Birth date and age|1953|10|31|df=yes}})<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/user/2778 |title=Professor Kelvyn Jones | British Academy |website=Britac.ac.uk |date=2015-04-09 |accessdate=2017-07-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/geography/news/2016/professor-kelvyn-jones-fba.html |title=2016: Professor Kelvyn Jones, FBA | School of Geographical Sciences | University of Bristol |website=Bristol.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-07-20}}</ref> is a British professor (Emeritus) of human [[quantitative geography]] at the [[University of Bristol]].<ref>[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/geography/people/kelvyn-jones/index.html Professor Kelvyn Jones.] University of Bristol. Retrieved 20 July 2017.</ref> He focuses on the quantitative modeling of social science data with complex structure through the application of [[Multilevel modeling for repeated measures|multilevel models]]; especially in relation to change and health outcomes.<ref name="researcherid.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.researcherid.com/rid/A-3939-2011|title=Kelvyn Jones A-3939-2011 - ResearcherID.com|website=Researcherid.com|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref>
{{Infobox scientist | honorific_prefix = | name = Kelvyn Jones | honorific_suffix = [[Fellow of the British Academy|FBA]],[[FLSW]],[[FAcSS]] | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Kelvyn Jones photographed in 2016.jpg | image_size = | image_upright = 0.6 | alt = | caption = Jones in 2016 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|10|31|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Rhondda]], [[Wales]] | death_date = <!--{{death date and age |YYYY|MM|DD |YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date)--> | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!--{{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}}--> | other_names = | pronounce = | residence = [[United Kingdom]] | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = [[Quantitative research|Quantitative social science]], [[Human geography|Human Geography]] | workplaces = University of Newcastle,University College Swansea,University of Reading,Portsmouth Polytechnic,University of Portsmouth,Bristol University,University of Leuven | patrons = | education = | alma_mater = BSc, PhD, [[University of Southampton]] | thesis_title = Geographical Variations in Mortality | thesis_url = https://eprints.soton.ac.uk/374881/1/81038431.pdf | thesis_year = 1980 | doctoral_advisor = (| doctoral_advisors = Neil Wrigley, David Pinder | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = Contributions to [[Multilevel model|Multilevel Modelling]]; [[Health geography|Health Geography]] | influences = [[Peter Haggett]], [[Ron Johnston (geographer)]], Graham Woosnam [[Socratic Method]] | influenced = | awards = [[Murchison Award]], 2013 | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = <!--(or | spouses = )--> | partner = <!--(or | partners = )--> | children = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = <!--{{URL|www.bristol.ac.uk/geography/people/kelvyn-jones/index.html}--> | footnotes = }}
== Academic controversies == He has been involved in a number of academic controversies, and these debates have been of a methodological and substantive nature. They include:
* He has disagreed with the [[Richard Wilkinson (public health)|Wilkinson inequality]] hypothesis that within country differences in health and mortality are driven by invidious comparison; instead arguing that there is a materialist argument based on poverty even in advanced economies.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2008.11.026 |title=Global variations in health: Evaluating Wilkinson's income inequality hypothesis using the World Values Survey |journal=Social Science & Medicine |volume=68 |issue=4 |pages=643–53 |year=2009 |last1=Jen |first1=Min Hua |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn |last3=Johnston |first3=Ron }}</ref> The argument is based on critique of Wilkinson's use of aggregate data and supports the ideas of [[Hugh Gravelle]] that if there is a non-linear individual relationship between income and ill-health then the aggregate relationship will necessarily involve the 'spread' (standard deviation) of country income that is inequality.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.healthplace.2008.04.005 |title=Compositional and contextual approaches to the study of health behaviour and outcomes: Using multi-level modelling to evaluate Wilkinson's income inequality hypothesis |journal=Health & Place |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=198–203 |year=2009 |last1=Jen |first1=Min Hua |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn |last3=Johnston |first3=Ron }}</ref> * He has argued against [[Growth in a Time of Debt]] thesis and (with Andy Bell) re-analyzed the Reinhart and Rogoff data to show that the evidence for many counties is that the relationship is around the other way - the lack of growth produces debt,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/jeg/lbu005 |title=Stylised fact or situated messiness? The diverse effects of increasing debt on national economic growth |journal=Journal of Economic Geography |volume=15 |issue=2 |pages=449–72 |year=2015 |last1=Bell |first1=Andrew |last2=Johnston |first2=Ron |last3=Jones |first3=Kelvyn }}</ref> and that the relationship between debt and growth varies significantly between countries, meaning that an average "rule", such as that suggested by Reinhart and Rogoff, has little meaning or policy relevance.<ref>{{cite web |first1=Kelvyn |last1=Jones |first2=Andrew |last2=Bell |first3=Ron |last3=Johnston |date=May 15, 2013 |title=Significant variation across countries means that simple conclusions regarding growth and debt, like those offered by Reinhart & Rogoff, have no policy relevance |url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/politicsandpolicy/debt-and-economic-growth-but-no-geography-a-cautionary-tale/ |work=British Politics and Policy blog }}{{self-published inline|date=August 2017}}</ref> * With colleagues, he has argued against [[Trevor Phillips]] that the UK is 'sleep walking to segregation', finding that ethnic residential segregation in London for example is decreasing.<ref name="auto">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/tran.12142 |title=Macro-scale stability with micro-scale diversity: Modelling changing ethnic minority residential segregation - London 2001-2011 |journal=Transactions of the Institute of British Geographers |volume=41 |issue=4 |pages=389–402 |year=2016 |last1=Johnston |first1=Ron |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn |last3=Manley |first3=David |last4=Owen |first4=Dewi }}</ref> They dispute that Muslim ghettoes are developing in British cities,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/0308518X16651873 |title=In search of Britain's Muslim ghettoes |journal=Environment and Planning A |volume=48 |issue=9 |pages=1684–90 |year=2016 |last1=Johnston |first1=Ron |last2=Manley |first2=David |last3=Jones |first3=Kelvyn }}</ref> and that Australian suburbs are being 'swamped' by Asians and Muslims.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/00049182.2017.1329383 |title=Are Australia's suburbs swamped by Asians and Muslims? Countering political claims with data |journal=[[Australian Geographer]] |volume=48 |issue=4 |pages=1–16 |year=2017 |last1=Forrest |first1=James |last2=Johnston |first2=Ron |last3=Siciliano |first3=Frank |last4=Manley |first4=David |last5=Jones |first5=Kelvyn }}</ref> * He has argued that quantitative analysis in the form of [[quantitative geography]] has an important role in emancipatory [[human geography]] (see [[critical geography]]). He has argued that this involves adopting a realist philosophy of science distinguished as [[critical realism (philosophy of the social sciences)|critical realism]] and not [[positivism]]. The arguments are made in "The Practice of Quantitative Methods"<ref>Jones,Kelvyn (2011)The Practice of Quantitative Methods in Somekh, Bridget and Lewin, Cathy (eds.) ''Theory and methods in social research'' Sage Publications Ltd, 201-211, download from https://www.researchgate.net/publication/256801634_The_practice_of_quantitative_methods</ref> and are further developed and exemplified with colleagues in "Mutual misunderstanding and avoidance, misrepresentations and disciplinary politics: spatial science and quantitative analysis in (United Kingdom) geographical curricula"<ref>Johnston R, Harris R, Jones K, et al (2014) Mutual mis-understanding and avoidance, mis-representations, and disciplinary politics: spatial science and quantitative analysis in (UK) geographical curricula. Dialogues in Human Geography 4(1): 3–25 https://www.researchgate.net/publication/261054447</ref> and a subsequent extended reply to critics in "One step forward but two steps back to the proper appreciation of spatial science".<ref>Johnston, R, et al. (2014) "One step forward but two steps back to the proper appreciation of spatial science." Dialogues in Human Geography 4.1 (2014): 59-69. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/261062153</ref> One commentator described this as "an extraordinary contribution. This is a panoramic survey of the legacy of half a century of innovation in spatial science—put into a critical, constructive engagement with half a century of innovation in critical social theory".<ref>Wyly, E. 2014. The new quantitative revolution. Dialogues in Human Geography 4(1): 26–38. http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/2043820614525732</ref> * He (with colleagues) has challenged the 'gold standard' that fixed effects should be the standard approach to the analysis of [[Panel data]] and that a Hausman test is an appropriate way of choosing between a [[Fixed effects model]] and a [[Random effects model]]. Somewhat controversially they argue that a particular form of the random effects model (the within-between model or the similar Mundlak model) offers all that fixed effects can provide and more.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1017/psrm.2014.7 |title=Explaining Fixed Effects: Random Effects Modeling of Time-Series Cross-Sectional and Panel Data |journal=Political Science Research and Methods |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=133–53 |year=2014 |last1=Bell |first1=Andrew |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/299604336_Fixed_and_Random_effects_making_an_informed_choice|title=Fixed and Random effects: making an informed choice (PDF Download Available)|website=ResearchGate|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/post/Is_there_some_other_method_other_than_hausman_test_to_decide_which_method_either_fixed_or_random_should_be_adopted_in_panel_data_analysis|title=Is there some other method other than hausman test to decide...|website=ResearchGate.net|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> They also challenge the Fixed Effects Vector Decomposition (FEVD) model of Plumper and Troeger.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www2.warwick.ac.uk/fac/soc/economics/staff/vetroeger/publications/pa2011_pluemper_troeger.pdf|format=PDF|journal=Political Analysis|date=2011|volume=19|issue=2|pages=147–164|doi=10.1093/pan/mpr008|title=Fixed-Effects Vector Decomposition: Properties, Reliability, and Instruments|author1=Thomas Plumper|author2=Vera E. Troeger}}</ref> One reaction was: "This paper and the instructive controversial over FEVD have shown me that my econometrics training had not - as I once assumed - taught me all that there is to know about fixed effects estimation. In particular, the authors' treatment of 'heterogeneity bias' clarifies the importance of addressing both 'within' and 'between' variation in the data and they make a compelling case for considering both 'individual' and 'ecological' influences".<ref>Geoffrey Thomas Pugh https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Geoffrey_Pugh/answers</ref> Another was: "Bizarre and often incorrect paper by two political scientists on the virtues of random-effects over fixed-effects".<ref>Tweet from Amitabh Chandra@amitabhchandra2</ref> to "You can and should use a well-specified random effects model. Always.".<ref>Panel data within group estimator on StackExchange demonstrates results with [[R (programming language)]] code https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/100168/panel-data-within-group-estimate-individual-fixed-effects-retrieved</ref> * He and colleagues argue that group-mean centering in multilevel models can be a useful procedure in random coefficient models,<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1007/s11135-017-0593-5|title= Understanding and misunderstanding group mean centering: a commentary on Kelley et al.’s dangerous practice |journal=Quality & Quantity |year=2017 |last1=Bell |first1=Andrew |last2=Jones |first2= Kelvyn |last3=Fairbrother |first3= Malcolm }}</ref> thereby disagreeing that it is a 'dangerous' procedure.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s11135-015-0304-z |title=Group-mean-centering independent variables in multi-level models is dangerous |journal=Quality & Quantity |volume=51 |pages=261–83 |year=2016 |last1=Kelley |first1=Jonathan |last2=Evans |first2=M. D. R. |last3=Lowman |first3=Jennifer |last4=Lykes |first4=Valerie}}</ref> Reactions to this critique include "may the Saints & Angels protect us from ever having a paper this thoroughly dismantled"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/polesasunder/status/931602710876639233/|title=Andrew MacDonald on Twitter|publisher=}}</ref> and "Seriously though, if you are interested in multilevel modelling I highly recommend this short, instructive and frankly rather sassy paper." <ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/polesasunder/status/931609848281817088|title=Andrew MacDonald on Twitter|publisher=}}</ref> * He contends that even with population data (e.g. a full enumeration of all pupils in all schools in a country), a statistical inference approach is required to deal with stochastic or natural variation. Observed outcomes are seen as a result of a stochastic process which could produce different results under the same circumstances. It is this underlying process that is of interest and the actual observed values give only an imprecise estimate of this.<ref name="auto1">{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s13524-015-0430-1 |pmid=26487190 |pmc=4644210 |title=Ethnic Residential Segregation: A Multilevel, Multigroup, Multiscale Approach Exemplified by London in 2011 |journal=Demography |volume=52 |issue=6 |pages=1995–2019 |year=2015 |last1=Jones |first1=Kelvyn |last2=Johnston |first2=Ron |last3=Manley |first3=David |last4=Owen |first4=Dewi |last5=Charlton |first5=Chris }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/post/Why_cant_a_statistical_test_of_significance_inferential_analysis_be_applied_to_a_population|title=Why can't a statistical test of significance (inferential...|website=ResearchGate.net|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/post/Are_p-values_and_significance_tests_still_meaningful_in_census_data_analysis|title=Are p-values and significance tests still meaningful in...|website=ResearchGate.net|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Working with Andy Bell, he has argued that the multilevel model (in the form of the hierarchical-age–period–cohort (HAPC) model) is not an automatic solution to the identification problem of the age period cohort model. This third-party site considers some earlier papers in the exchange between Bell and Jones and Yang and Land,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://maksimrudnev.com/2015/07/20/recent-clarifications-in-age-period-cohort-analysis/|title=Recent clarifications in age-period-cohort analysis|first=Dwayne Woods|last=says|date=20 July 2015|website=Makimrudnev.com|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> while this most recent paper gives in Table 1 the key papers (and arguments made).;<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s11135-017-0488-5 |title=The hierarchical age–period–cohort model: Why does it find the results that it finds? |journal=Quality & Quantity |year=2017 |last1=Bell |first1=Andrew |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn }}</ref> the full list of papers that Bell and Jones have written are available for download from Research Gate.<ref>Age-period- cohort project site on Research Gate: https://www.researchgate.net/project/Age-period-cohort</ref>
== Academic work and projects == He researches in three main areas:<ref>These are listed on his University of Bristol website: http://www.bristol.ac.uk/geography/people/kelvyn-jones/research.html</ref>
* Geography of health: particularly geographical inequalities in mortality in advanced economies; * Research design: especially to develop evidence-based research in non-experimental, observational studies; * Realistically complex modelling: this research work focuses on the quantitative analysis of social-science data with complex structure, particularly when there are many levels of analysis such as panels, spatial series, and space-time series.
His substantive and methodological work is wide-ranging and includes the following bodies of work:
Substantive research * Geography of health <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Geography-of-health|title=Geography of health|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Macro determinants of health;<ref>Project site on Research Gate: https://www.researchgate.net/project/Macro-determinants-of-health</ref> * Multilevel modelling of health-related behaviors and outcomes <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Multilevel-modelling-of-health-related-behaviors-and-outcomes|title=Multilevel modelling of health-related behaviors and outcomes|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Multilevel modelling of mental health outcomes<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Multilevel-modelling-of-mental-health-outcomes|title=Multilevel modelling of mental health outcomes|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Multilevel modelling of social capital, trust and volunteering <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Multilevel-modelling-of-social-capital-trust-and-volunteering|title=Multilevel modelling of social capital, trust and volunteering|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Multilevel modelling of voting behaviors and electoral outcomes <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Multilevel-modelling-of-voting-behaviors-and-electoral-outcomes|title=Multilevel modelling of voting behaviors and electoral outcomes|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Forecasting geographical variations in the EU referendum<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Forecasting-geographical-variations-in-the-EU-referendum|title=Forecasting geographical variations in the EU referendum|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Multilevel modelling of socio-demographic variation in China <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Multilevel-modelling-of-socio-demographic-variation-in-China|title=Multilevel modelling of socio-demographic variation in China|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Modelling segregation: applying the new methodologies <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Modelling-segregation-applying-the-new-methdologies|title=Modelling segregation: applying the new methdologies|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Multilevel modelling of property(house) prices <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Multilevel-modelling-of-propertyhouse-prices|title=Multilevel modelling of property(house) prices|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Multilevel modelling of sporting outcomes <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Multilevel-modelling-of-sporting-outcomes|title=Multilevel modelling of sporting outcomes|website=ResearchGate}}</ref>
Methodological research * Quantitative geography <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Quantitative-geography|title=Quantitative geography|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Statistical data analysis in the social sciences <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Statistical-data-analysis-in-the-social-sciences-non-multilevel-papers|title=Statistical data analysis in the social sciences (non multilevel papers)|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Multilevel modelling: scope, models and issues<ref>{{cite software, manuals and data <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Multilevel-analysis-software-manuals-and-data-as-worksheets|title=Multilevel analysis, software, manuals and data (as worksheets)|website=ResearchGate}}</ref> * Fixed and Random effects analysis <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/project/Fixed-and-Random-effects|title=Fixed and Random == Access to publications and citations == * A Google Scholar profile gives up-to-date citation of his work.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.co.uk/citations?user=3TAGmZkAAAAJ|title=Kelvyn Jones, FBA FLSW - Google Scholar Citations|website=scholar.google.co.uk|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * He makes available much of his academic output on Research Gate,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Kelvyn_Jones|title=Kelvyn Jones|website=ResearchGate.net|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> where he frequently answers questions on statistical (especially multilevel) modeling.;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Kelvyn_Jones/answers|title=Log in|website=ResearchGate.net|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> he has also explained his reasons for doing so in answer to a question on the site <ref>Which_researcher_has_the_highest_RG_score_and_what_does_that_really_mean?https://www.researchgate.net/post/Which_researcher_has_the_highest_RG_score_and_what_does_that_really_mean/1</ref> As of November 2018, he has had over 0.5 million 'reads' on Research Gate and this is accruing at a rate of around 10,000 per week.<ref> Research Gate weekly statistics at https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Kelvyn_Jones/stats</ref> * There are also a [[ResearcherID]] site;<ref name="researcherid.com"/> an [[ORCID]] site;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://orcid.org/0000-0001-8398-2190|title=Kelvyn Jones (0000-0001-8398-2190) - ORCID - Connecting Research and Researchers|website=Orcid.org|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> and a database of publications at the University of Bristol.<ref>University of Bristol Kelvyn Jones Research Outputs http://research-information.bristol.ac.uk/en/persons/kelvyn-jones(d70b4392-03cc-48b4-a3d8-d3cd6a2e3a3c)/publications.html</ref>
== Posts held ==
University of Newcastle, 1978-1979, Lecturer in Geography,;<ref>According to entry in [[Who's Who (UK)]]</ref> University College Swansea, 1979-1980, Lecturer in Geography; University of Reading, 1980-1981 SSRC Postdoctoral Fellow; Portsmouth Polytechnic (post 1992, University of Portsmouth) 1981- 1994, Lecturer, Principal Lecturer, Reader; Portsmouth University, 1994-2000, Professor of Geography (Personal Chair), Head of School (1997-2000); Catholic University of Brussels, 1992-2011, Professor of Social Science Methodology; University of Bristol, 2001-2018 Professor of Geography, (Personal Chair) (Head of School, 2005-2009 ); University of Bristol, 2018- Emeritus Professor of Geography; University of Leuven, 2011- Professor at Leuven Statistics Research Centre (LStat).
His and other reflections on his time at Portsmouth (Polytechnic and University) were produced on his election to the British Academy <ref>{{cite web|url=http://uopnews.port.ac.uk/2016/07/20/prestigious-honour-for-former-university-professor/|title=Prestigious honour for former professor - UoP News|website=uopnews.port.ac.uk}}</ref>
Voluntary positions include: RAE Panel Member for Geography 2001;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rae.ac.uk/2001/PMembers/Panel35.htm|title=Panel Members|website=www.rae.ac.uk}}</ref> RAE Panel Member for Geography and Environmental Studies 2008;<ref>http://www.rae.ac.uk/pubs/2007/03/mainpanelH.pdf</ref> Board Member of Bristol University Press, 2018-;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bristoluniversitypress.co.uk/|title=Bristol University Press|website=Bristol University Press}}</ref> Member of Understanding Society Scientific Advisory Committee, 2018-;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.understandingsociety.ac.uk/about/team|title=Meet the team - Understanding Society|website=www.understandingsociety.ac.uk}}</ref> Scrutiny Committee for Fellowship of the Learned Society of Wales (Economic and Social Sciences, Education and Law), 2016-.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.learnedsociety.wales/our-fellows/fellowship-election-cycle/scrutiny-committees/b3/|title=B3 Economic and Social Sciences, Education and Law - The Learned Society of Wales|first=The Learned Society of|last=Wales|publisher=}}</ref>
==Recognition and awards== The election to a Fellowship of the British Academy was in 2016 and he was elected both to Sociology, Demography and Social Statistics (Section 4) and to Anthropology and Geography (Section 3)). The citation on election reads ‘Kelvyn Jones is an internationally leading quantitative social scientist. He has made major contributions to the analysis and interpretation of large and complex data sets in a broad field of quantitative social sciences, including geography, and is extremely active in promoting training in quantitative analysis in the social sciences.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/geography/people/kelvyn-jones/index.html|title=Professor Kelvyn Jones - School of Geographical Sciences|first=University of|last=Bristol|website=Bristol.ac.uk|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> He is also a Fellow of the Learned Society of Wales, having been elected in 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.learnedsociety.wales/fellow/kelvyn-jones/|title=Kelvyn Jones - The Learned Society of Wales|website=Learnedsociety.wales|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> and an Academician of the Social Sciences, elected in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.acss.org.uk/fellows/#|title=Fellows - Academy of Social Sciences|website=Acss.org.uk|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> He was awarded the [[Murchison Award]] of the [[Royal Geographical Society]] in 2013 for his contribution to quantitative geography;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rgs.org/AboutUs/Medals+and+awards/2013+medals+and+awards.htm|title=2013 medals and awards|website=Rgs.org|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> an account of the ceremony was published in ''[[The Geographical Journal]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/geoj.12049 |title=Geographical connections: Royal Geographical Society (with IBG) Medals and Awards ceremony 2013 |journal=The Geographical Journal |volume=179 |issue=3 |pages=283–90 |year=2013 |last1=Rees |first1=Judith |last2=Palin |first2=Michael |last3=Richards |first3=Keith |last4=Jones |first4=Kelvyn |last5=Longley |first5=Paul |last6=Page |first6=Susan }}</ref>
{{As of|2009}}, he was listed in the top 20 most cited human geographers of the last half century.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/jeg/lbp061 |title=Measuring the influentialness of economic geographers during the 'great half century': An approach using the h index |journal=Journal of Economic Geography |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages=141–56 |year=2009 |last1=Bodman |first1=A. R. }}</ref><ref>Measuring the influentialness of economic geographers: career h indexes for human geographers {{cite web |url=https://courses.nus.edu.sg/course/geoywc/aboutme/Bodman_2010_Table1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170813183808/https://courses.nus.edu.sg/course/geoywc/aboutme/Bodman_2010_Table1.htm |archivedate=2017-08-13 |df= }}</ref> and since then his [[h-index]] as measured by Researcher ID has increased from 20 to 33 in 2018;<ref>http://www.researcherid.com/ProfileView.action?returnCode=ROUTER.Unauthorized&Init=Yes&SrcApp=CR&queryString=KG0UuZjN5WmCiHc%252FMC4oLdTvKslQVFoIzv60bzto4w0%253D</ref> comparable figures for different social sciences can be found in the LSE impact blog.<ref>LSE impact blog Chapter 3 Key measures of academic influence http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/impactofsocialsciences/the-handbook/chapter-3-key-measures-of-academic-influence/</ref> His Rgate Score as of November 2018 is over 230,<ref>https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Kelvyn_Jones/reputation</ref> and that compares to the outlying high scores of over 100 identified by E. Oduna-Malea et al., 2017 <ref E. Orduna-Malea, A. Martín-Martín, M. Thelwall, E. Delgado López-Cózar Do ResearchGate Scores create ghost academic reputations? Scientometrics, 112 (1) (2017), pp. 443-460 >https://www.researchgate.net/publication/316573798_Do_ResearchGate_Scores_create_ghost_academic_reputations</ref> reflecting his willingness to answer questions.
== Postgraduate teaching and supervision == He has taught a course on multilevel modeling annually at the Essex Summer School in Social Science Data analysis since 1992<ref>Essex Summer School http://essexsummerschool.com/</ref> and is a long term contributor to the Masters in Statistics and the Masters in Quantitative Social Science at the Leuven Statistics Research Centre.<ref>LSTAT https://lstat.kuleuven.be/</ref> He also two led two five-day workshops (2009 and 2011) in Pennsylvania State University and UC Santa Barbara under the aegis of GISpopsci.org.<ref>GISpopsci.org http://gispopsci.org/multilevel-modeling/</ref>
He has supervised a number of students for their PhD; they include: * Andrew Clegg<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0277-9536(91)90332-7 |title=Ecological and individual effects in childhood immunisation uptake: A multi-level approach |journal=Social Science & Medicine |volume=33 |issue=4 |pages=501 |year=1991 |last1=Jones |first1=Kelvyn |last2=Moon |first2=Graham |last3=Clegg |first3=Andrew }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clahrc-nwc.nihr.ac.uk/blog-post.php?t|title=Blog Post|website=Clahrc-nwc.nihr.ac.uk|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Craig Duncan<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1538-4632.2000.tb00429.x |title=Using Multilevel Models to Model Heterogeneity: Potential and Pitfalls |journal=Geographical Analysis |volume=32 |issue=4 |pages=279 |year=2010 |last1=Duncan |first1=Craig |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0277-9536(98)00360-8 |title=Smoking and deprivation: Are there neighbourhood effects? |journal=Social Science & Medicine |volume=48 |issue=4 |pages=497 |year=1999 |last1=Duncan |first1=Craig |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn |last3=Moon |first3=Graham }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0277-9536(97)00148-2 |title=Context, composition and heterogeneity: Using multilevel models in health research |journal=Social Science & Medicine |volume=46 |pages=97 |year=1998 |last1=Duncan |first1=Craig |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn |last3=Moon |first3=Graham }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0277-9536(95)00181-6 |title=Health-related behaviour in context: A multilevel modelling approach |journal=Social Science & Medicine |volume=42 |issue=6 |pages=817 |year=1996 |last1=Duncan |first1=Craig |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn |last3=Moon |first3=Graham }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.port.ac.uk/department-of-geography/staff/craig-duncan.html|title=Staff: Dr Craig Duncan - University of Portsmouth|website=Port.ac.uk|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Nina Bullen<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/00420989320081341 |title=A Multi-level Analysis of the Variations in Domestic Property Prices: Southern England, 1980-87 |journal=Urban Studies |volume=30 |issue=8 |pages=1409 |year=2016 |last1=Jones |first1=Kelvyn |last2=Bullen |first2=Nina }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1068/a290585 |title=Modelling Complexity: Analysing Between-Individual and Between-Place Variation—A Multilevel Tutorial |journal=Environment and Planning A |volume=29 |issue=4 |pages=585 |year=2016 |last1=Bullen |first1=N |last2=Jones |first2=K |last3=Duncan |first3=C }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/143993 |jstor=143993 |title=Contextual Models of Urban House Prices: A Comparison of Fixed- and Random-Coefficient Models Developed by Expansion |journal=Economic Geography |volume=70 |issue=3 |pages=252–72 |year=1994 |last1=Jones |first1=Kelvyn |last2=Bullen |first2=Nina }}</ref> * SV Subramanian<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1068/a3357 |title=Multilevel Perspectives on Modeling Census Data |journal=Environment and Planning A |volume=33 |issue=3 |pages=399 |year=2001 |last1=Subramanian |first1=S V |last2=Duncan |first2=Craig |last3=Jones |first3=Kelvyn }}</ref><ref>Subramanian, S. V., Duncan, C., & Jones, K. (2000). “Illiterate people” and “illiterate places”: The Indian Evidence. Indian Social Science Review, 2(2), 237-274.https://www.researchgate.net/publication/240038290_Illiterate_people''or''Illiterate_places''_the_Indian_evidence</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/sv-subramanian/|title=S V Subramanian|website=S V Subramanian|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Sarah Johns<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kent.ac.uk/sac/staff-profiles/profiles/biological-anthropology/academic-staff/johns_sarah.html|title=Dr Sarah Johns - School of Anthropology & Conservation - University of Kent|website=Kent.ac.uk|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Katherine French<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2005.08.002 |title=Impact of definition on the study of avoidable mortality: Geographical trends in British deaths 1981–1998 using Charlton and Holland's definitions |journal=Social Science & Medicine |volume=62 |issue=6 |pages=1443–56 |year=2006 |last1=French |first1=Katherine Meriel |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn }}</ref> * Min-Hua Jen<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.healthplace.2010.06.008 |title=Trustful societies, trustful individuals, and health: An analysis of self-rated health and social trust using the World Value Survey |journal=Health & Place |volume=16 |issue=5 |pages=1022 |year=2010 |last1=Jen |first1=Min Hua |last2=Sund |first2=Erik R |last3=Johnston |first3=Ron |last4=Jones |first4=Kelvyn }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1467-9663.2009.00518.x |title=International Variations in Life Expectancy: A Spatio-Temporal Analysis |journal=Tijdschrift voor economische en sociale geografie |volume=101 |pages=73 |year=2010 |last1=Jen |first1=MIN HUA |last2=Johnston |first2=RON |last3=Jones |first3=Kelvyn |last4=Harris |first4=Richard |last5=Gandy |first5=Axel }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.healthplace.2008.04.005 |title=Compositional and contextual approaches to the study of health behaviour and outcomes: Using multi-level modelling to evaluate Wilkinson's income inequality hypothesis |journal=Health & Place |volume=15 |pages=198 |year=2009 |last1=Jen |first1=Min Hua |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn |last3=Johnston |first3=Ron }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2008.11.026 |title=Global variations in health: Evaluating Wilkinson's income inequality hypothesis using the World Values Survey |journal=Social Science & Medicine |volume=68 |issue=4 |pages=643 |year=2009 |last1=Jen |first1=Min Hua |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn |last3=Johnston |first3=Ron }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Min-Hua_Jen|title=Min-Hua Jen|website=ResearchGate.net|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Beatriz Caicedo Velasquez<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.15446/rsap.v16n2.38983 |title=The role of the neighborhood, family and peers regarding Colombian adolescents' social context and aggressive behavior |journal=Revista de Salud Pública |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=208 |year=2014 |last1=Caicedo |first1=Beatriz |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.15446/rsap.v16n1.38665 |title=Investigating neighbourhood effects on health: Using community-survey data for developing neighbourhood-related constructs |journal=Revista de Salud Pública |volume=16 |pages=88 |year=2014 |last1=Caicedo |first1=Beatriz |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Beatriz_Caicedo2|title=Beatriz Caicedo|website=ResearchGate.net|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Caroline Wright- Commendations for PhD thesis and viva in the academic year 2014-15 <ref>Bristol Faculty of Science commendations for PhD thesis and viva,2014-15 http://www.bris.ac.uk/science/courses/postgraduate/pg-commendations-1415/</ref><ref>Do multilevel models ever give different results? https://www.researchgate.net/publication/252146040_Do_multilevel_models_ever_give_different_results</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/social-community-medicine/people/caroline-l-wright/index.html|title=Dr Caroline Wright - School of Social and Community Medicine|first=University of|last=Bristol|website=Bristol.ac.uk|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Zhixin 'Frank' Feng -winner of the 2013 Faculty Research Prize <ref>Zhixin Feng wins Faculty Research Prize University of Bristol https://bris.ac.uk/news/2013/9933.html</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2012.09.028 |title=An exploratory multilevel analysis of income, income inequality and self-rated health of the elderly in China |journal=Social Science & Medicine |volume=75 |issue=12 |pages=2481 |year=2012 |last1=Feng |first1=Zhixin |last2=Wang |first2=Wenfei Winnie |last3=Jones |first3=Kelvyn |last4=Li |first4=Yaqing |pmc=3696131 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.healthplace.2013.07.001 |title=A multilevel analysis of the role of the family and the state in self-rated health of elderly Chinese |journal=Health & Place |volume=23 |pages=148 |year=2013 |last1=Feng |first1=Zhixin |last2=Wang |first2=Wenfei Winnie |last3=Jones |first3=Kelvyn }}</ref><ref>Feng, Z., Jones, K., & Wang, W. (2015) An exploratory discrete-time multilevel analysis of the effect of social support on the survival of the elderly in China. Social Science & Medicine, 130, 181-189.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/s12939-016-0469-7 |title=Social trust, interpersonal trust and self-rated health in China: A multi-level study |journal=International Journal for Equity in Health |volume=15 |year=2016 |last1=Feng |first1=Zhixin |last2=Vlachantoni |first2=Athina |last3=Liu |first3=Xiaoting |last4=Jones |first4=Kelvyn }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.southampton.ac.uk/ageing/about/staff/zf1f12.page|title=Dr Zhixin Frank Feng - Social Sciences: Ageing/Gerontology - University of Southampton|website=Southampton.ac.uk|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Andrew Bell<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1017/psrm.2014.7 |title=Explaining Fixed Effects: Random Effects Modeling of Time-Series Cross-Sectional and Panel Data |journal=Political Science Research and Methods |volume=3 |pages=133 |year=2014 |last1=Bell |first1=Andrew |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn }}</ref><ref>Bell, A., & Jones, K. (2014). Another'futile quest'? A simulation study of Yang and Land's Hierarchical Age-Period-Cohort model. Demographic Research, 30, 333. https://www.demographic-research.org/Volumes/Vol30/11/</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2013.04.029 |title=The impossibility of separating age, period and cohort effects |journal=Social Science & Medicine |volume=93 |pages=163 |year=2013 |last1=Bell |first1=Andrew |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/smi/about-us/andrew-bell|title=Andrew Bell - About us - Sheffield Methods Institute - The University of Sheffield|first=University of|last=Sheffield|website=Sheffield.ac.uk|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Dewi Owen<ref name="auto1"/><ref name="auto"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Dewi_Owen|title=Dewi Owen|website=ResearchGate.net|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Yingyu Feng<ref>{{cite book |doi=10.1109/ICSDM.2015.7298035 |chapter=Comparing multilevel modelling and artificial neural networks in house price prediction |title=2015 2nd IEEE International Conference on Spatial Data Mining and Geographical Knowledge Services (ICSDM) |pages=108–114 |year=2015 |last1=Feng |first1=Yingyu |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn |isbn=978-1-4799-7748-2 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=FENG, Y.|author2=JONES, K.|date=2016|title=COMPARING TWO NEIGHBOURHOOD CLASSIFICATiONS: A MULTILEVEL ANALYSIS OF LONDON PROPERTY PRICE IN 2011-2014|url=http://www.prres.net/Proceedings/..%5CPapers%5CFENG_COMPARING_TWO_NEIGHBOURHOODS.pdf|format=PDF|website=Prres.net|accessdate=2017-09-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Yingyu_Feng/publications|title=Yingyu Feng - Publications|website=ResearchGate.net|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * Gwilym Owen- Winner of the Faculty prize for Best Doctoral Research Thesis 2016/17<ref>Gwilym Owen best doctoral thesis Faculty of Social Sciences and Law Bristol http://www.bris.ac.uk/news/2017/october/best-theses.html</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/0309132515580814 |title=Under examination |journal=Progress in Human Geography |volume=40 |issue=3 |pages=394–412 |year=2015 |last1=Owen |first1=Gwilym |last2=Harris |first2=Richard |last3=Jones |first3=Kelvyn }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2017.05.041 |title=Does neighbourhood deprivation affect the genetic influence on body mass? |journal=Social Science & Medicine |volume=185 |pages=38–45 |year=2017 |last1=Owen |first1=Gwilym |last2=Jones |first2=Kelvyn |last3=Harris |first3=Richard }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Gwilym_Owen|title=Gwilym Owen|website=ResearchGate.net|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref>
== Major publications == Book length publications include:
* Jones, Kelvyn and Moon, Graham (1987). Health, disease and society: a critical medical geography, Routledge & Kegan Paul Ltd, London.<ref>Extract of Health, Disease and Society on Research Gate https://www.researchgate.net/publication/234015155_Health_Disease_and_Society_A_Critical_Medical_Geography</ref> * Jones Kelvyn (1991). Multi-level Models for Geographical Research, Environmental Publications, Norwich.<ref>Full text of Multilevel models for geographical research available at http://www.ggy.bris.ac.uk/personal/KelvynJones/54-multi-level-models.pdf</ref> * Moon, Graham; Gould, Myles; Jones, Kelvyn et al. (2000). Epidemiology, Open University Press, Buckingham.<ref>Extracts of Epidemiology on <Research Gate https://www.researchgate.net/publication/236671039_Epidemiology_An_Introduction</ref> * Mohan, John; Barnard, Steve; Jones, Kelvyn and Twigg, Lizbeth (2004). Social capital, place and health: creating, validating and applying small-area indicators in the modelling of health outcomes, Health Development Agency.<ref>Full text of Social capital, place and health available on Research Gate https://www.researchgate.net/publication/242472074/</ref> * Jones, Kelvyn and Subramanian, SV (2014). Developing multilevel models for analysing contextuality, heterogeneity and change using MLwiN, Volume 1, Centre for Multilevel Modelling, University of Bristol, United Kingdom.<ref>Developing multilevel models for analysing contextuality, heterogeneity and change: Complete Volume 1 https://www.researchgate.net/publication/260771330</ref> * Jones, Kelvyn and Subramanian, SV (2013). Developing multilevel models for analysing contextuality, heterogeneity and change using MLwiN, Volume 2, Centre for Multilevel Modelling, University of Bristol, United Kingdom.<ref>Developing multilevel models for analysing contextuality, heterogeneity and change: Complete Volume 2 https://www.researchgate.net/publication/260772180</ref>
