page.title: List of Armenian territories and states

revision.comment: Replacing Artaxiad.svg with [[File:Standard_of_the_Artaxiad_dynasty.svg]] (by [[commons:User:CommonsDelinker|CommonsDelinker]] because: [[:c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: [[:c:COM:FR#FR2|Criterion 2]] (meaningless or ambiguous name)).
revision.text:
{{Armenians}} {{Main|History of Armenia}}
This is a list of '''Armenian states, countries and regions''' throughout [[history]]. It includes [[empire]]s, [[Country|countries]], [[Sovereign state|states]], [[provinces]], [[Autonomous region|regions]] and [[Territory (administrative division)|territories]] that have or had in the past one of the following characteristics: *An [[Armenians|ethnic Armenian]] majority or significant portion of it *Armenians are an official, constitutional or titular nation *[[Armenian language|Armenian ]] as an [[official language]] or the native language of the majority *An Armenian ruling class or dynasty
==Prehistoric Armenia== *[[Nairi]] *[[Hayasa-Azzi]]
== Historical political entities == === Early === *[[Kingdom of Urartu]] (860 BC–590 BC) *[[Satrapy of Armenia|Orontid Armenia]] (6th century BC – 2nd century BC) *[[File:Standard of the Artaxiad dynasty.svg|22px]] [[Kingdom of Armenia (antiquity)|Kingdom of Armenia]] (331 BC–428 AD)
===Medievial=== *[[Emirate of Armenia]] (637–884) *[[File:Bagratuni flag.svg|22px]] [[Kingdom of Armenia (Middle Ages)|Bagratid Armenia]] (885–1045) *[[Vaspurakan Kingdom]] (908–1021) - a regional kingdom in [[Vaspurakan]] region *[[Kingdom of Lori]] (979–1118) - a regional kingdom in [[Lori Province|Lori]] region *[[File:Rubenid Flag.svg|22px]] [[Armenian Kingdom of Cilicia]] (1198–1375) *[[Zakarid Armenia]] (1201–1330s) *[[File:Armenian Flag Khachen.gif|22px]] [[Principality of Khachen]] (11th century – 1750)
== Modern political entities == [[File:Armenia between russian and ottoman empires.png|thumb|250px|Early 20th century: Western (Ottoman) and Eastern (Russian) Armenias.]] === {{flag|Ottoman Empire}} === {| ! <big>Before 1864</big> ! <big>1864-1923</big> |- style="vertical-align:top; white-space:nowrap;" | *[[Erzurum Eyalet]] *[[Adana Eyalet]] *[[Eyalet of Diyarbekir]] *[[Kars Eyalet]] *[[Eyalet of Childir]] *[[Eyalet of Van]] | '''[[Six Armenian vilayets]]''' #[[Bitlis Vilayet]] #[[Erzurum Vilayet]] #[[Diyarbekir Vilayet]] #[[Mamuretülaziz Vilayet]] #[[Van Vilayet]] #[[Sivas Vilayet]] ---- *[[Adana Vilayet]] *[[Ankara Vilayet]] *[[Trebizond Vilayet]] |}
=== {{flag|Russian Empire}} === *[[File:Caucasian COA(Russian Empire).jpg|15px]] [[Armenian Oblast]] (1828-1840) - about half of the population *[[File:Coat of Arms of Erivan gubernia (Russian empire).png|20px]] [[Erivan Governorate]] (1850-1917) - a little more than half of the population *[[File:Karobl.png|20px]] [[Kars Oblast]] (1878-1918) - about 1/4 of the population, plurality *[[File:Елисаветпольская губ МВД Бенке.jpg|20px]] [[Elisabethpol Governorate]] (1868-1917) - about 1/3 of the population; majority in Shusha ''uyezd'', significant part of Kazakh and Zangezur ''uyezds'' population *[[File:Тифлисская губ МВД Бенке.jpg|20px]] [[Tiflis Governorate]] (1847-1917) - about 1/5 of the population; majority in Akhalkalaki ''uyezd'', plurality in Borchali ''uyezds'', second ethnic group in Akhaltsikhe ''uyezd''
=== World War I and later years === *[[Republic of Van]] (1915-1918) in the Armenian-inhabited areas of the Ottoman Empire occupied by the Russian Empire *[[Special Transcaucasian Committee]] (1917) included the Armenian inhabited regions of the Russian Empire *[[Transcaucasian Commissariat]] (1917-1918) included the Armenian inhabited regions of the Russian Empire *[[File:Flag of the Transcaucasian Federation.svg|22px]] [[Transcaucasian Democratic Federative Republic]] (1918) included the Armenian inhabited regions of the Russian Empire *{{flagicon|Armenia}} [[Democratic Republic of Armenia]] (1918-1920) was first-ever modern Armenian state *{{flagicon|Armenia}} [[Republic of Mountainous Armenia]] (1921) was formed in [[Syunik Province|Syunik]], [[Vayots Dzor]] and some parts of [[Karabakh]]
=== {{flag|Soviet Union}} === *[[File:Flag of Armenian SSR.svg|22px]] [[Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic]] (1920-1991) *[[Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast]] within [[Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic]] (1923-1991) - about 3/4 of the total population
== Present political entities == This is the list of the current states and regions where Armenians are in absolute or relative ethnic majority, are one of the constitutional or recognized peoples or Armenian language is official: *{{flagicon|Armenia}} [[Republic of Armenia]] *{{flagicon|Nagorno-Karabakh}} [[Nagorno-Karabakh Republic]] - unrecognized state, ''de jure'' part of [[Azerbaijan Republic]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== See also == * [[Greater Armenia (political concept)|United Armenia]], irrendentist claim to regions historically and currently populated by Armenians

page.title: List of Czech regions by GDP
List of English translated personal names

revision.comment: Removing name that hasn't been Anglicized.
revision.text:
{{cleanup|reason=Inconsistent list formatting|date=February 2017}} __TOC__ The list does not include names which are commonly translated by the common set of English first names: * names of biblical figures ([[Abraham]]), saints ([[John of the Cross]]), popes ([[John Paul II]]), * royalty, nobility and emperors ([[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor]], [[Napoleon]]) It also does not include: * pseudonyms and stagenames (such as the librettist [[Metastasio]]) * naturalised name changes (such as [[George Frideric Handel]] born [[Georg Friedrich Händel]], naturalised British subject in 1727, [[Arnold Schoenberg]], born Arnold Schönberg, US citizen in 1941)<ref>John R. Shook – Dictionary of Modern American Philosophers: Volume 1 – 2005 Page 2153 "He became a US citizen in 1941, thereafter spelling his name as Schoenberg."</ref>
Modern convention is not to translate modern personal names.<ref>''Journal of the Kafka Society of America'' Kafka Society of America 2003 Volume 27, Nos 1 & 2 – Page 54 "To begin with false notes, the conventional recent practice among translators has been not to translate personal names, and we might therefore think of the transformation of the German Georg into an English George (Jolas, Beuscher, ."</ref>
==Anglicized names== <!-- Alphabetical order by last name --> * John Abeel (c.1732–1836), English/Dutch name of Seneca diplomat Gaiänt'wakê; also used the more literal English translation "[[Cornplanter]]," which is in more common use today * [[Mark Antony]] (or Marc Antony) (83–30 BCE), Roman military leader and politician – from Latin Marcus Antonius * [[Thomas Aquinas]] (1225–1274), Italian theologian, Tommaso d'Aquino * [[Theodore Beza]] (1519–1605), original first name plus Latinized surname of French theologian ''Théodore de Bèze''. * George Brankovic (1461–1516), [[Đorđe Branković]], Serbian despot * [[Joseph Brant]] (1743–1807), English name of Seneca warrior Thayendanegea * [[John Cabot]] (1450–1499), Italian navigator and explorer under the commission of Henry VII of England – from Venetian ''Zuan Chabotto''. * [[John Calvin]] (1509–1564), Swiss-French theologian – from French [[Jean Calvin]] * [[Catiline]] (108–62 BCE), politician and conspirator – from Latin [[Lucius Sergius Catilina]], anglicised [[cognomen]] * [[Christopher Columbus]] (1451–1506), navigator and explorer – from Italian ''Cristoforo Colombo'' * [[Peter of Bruys]] (fl. 1117 – c. 1131), French preacher – from Pierre de Bruys * [[Peter Damian]] (c. 1007 – 1072), Italian cardinal – from Italian ''Pietro Damiani'', Latin ''Petrus Damiani''. * Francis David (c. 1510 – 1579), old anglicization of Hungarian non-trinitarian [[Ferenc Dávid]]. * [[Denis the Carthusian]] (1402–1471), Dutch mystic Denys van Leeuwen. * George Enyedi (1555–1597), old anglicization of Hungarian bishop [[György Enyedi (Unitarian)]], in Latin Georgius Eniedinus * [[Hugo Etherianis]] (1115–1182) Italian secretary in Constantinople, Latin Hugh Etherianus from Italian Ugo Eteriano. * [[Pete Fountain]] (1930–2016), English name of Louisiana French clarinetist Pierre LaFontaine, Jr. * [[Henry of Ghent]] (c. 1217 – 1293), French Augustinian, from Latin Henricus de Gandavo, French Henri de Gand. * [[Eduard Khil|Edward Hill]] (1934–2012), anglicized name of Russian singer Эдуа́рд Хиль * [[Homer]] (c. 8th – 7th century BCE), poet – from Greek Ὅμηρος (Hómēros). * [[Horace]] (65–8 BCE), poet – from Latin [[Quintus Horatius Flaccus]], anglicised [[nomen gentile]]. * [[John of Damascus]] (645 or 676 – 749) Syrian monk and priest, Greek Ἰωάννης ὁ Δαμασκηνός Iōannēs ho Damaskēnos, from Arabic Yuḥannā Al Demashqi. * John Hus (1369–1415), Czech religious reformer – now more normally referred to by Czech name [[Jan Hus]]. * [[Thomas à Kempis]] (1380–1471), German theologian – English use of French name, from German [[:de:Thomas von Kempen]]. * [[Livy]] (59 BCE–17 CE), historian – from Latin [[Titus Livius Patavinus]], anglicised [[nomen gentile]]. * [[Peter Lombard]], (c. 1096 – 1164) Italian theologian – Latin Petrus Lombardus, Italian Pietro Lombardo * [[Ferdinand Magellan]] (c. 1480 – 1521) navigator and explorer – from Portuguese [[Fernão de Magalhães]]. * [[Maimonides]] (1135–1204) Greek name of Mosheh ben Maimon (משה בן מימון) of Cordova who wrote in Arabic as Mūsā ibn Maymūn. * [[Nahmanides]] (1194 – c. 1270), Greek name of Moshe ben Nahman, Catalan rabbi. * [[Ovid]] (43 BCE–17/18 CE), poet – from Latin [[Publius Ovidius Naso]], anglicised [[nomen gentile]]. * [[Paul of Venice]] (1368–1428) Italian theologian – Latin Paulus Venetus, Italian Paolo da Venezia. * [[Peter of Ravenna]] (c. 1448 – 1508) Italian jurist – Pietro da Ravenna * [[Petrarch]] (1304–1374), anglicized version of the Latin surname Petrarca, from the original name of the poet Francesco Petracco. * [[Pompey]] (106–48 BCE), Roman military leader and politician – from Latin Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus * [[William of Saliceto|William of Salicet]] (1210–1277) Italian surgeon Guglielmo da Saliceto * [[George Santayana]] (1863–1952), English name of Spanish-American writer Jorge Agustín Nicolás Ruiz de Santayana y Borrás * [[Nicolas Steno]] (1638–1686), anatomist, geologist and bishop (and saint) – abbreviation of Latin ''Stenonis'' from Danish [[Niels Stensen]]. * [[Terence]] (195/185–159 BCE), dramatist – from Latin [[Publius Terentius Afer]], anglicised [[nomen gentile]]. * [[Peter Waldo]] (c. 1140 – c. 1218), French religious reformer Pierre Vaudès.
==Latinized names used in English== Also see [[List of Latinised names]]. <!-- Alphabetical order by last name --> * [[Georgius Agricola]] (1494–1555) Latin name of German mineralogist Georg Bauer or Georg Pawer. * [[Rodolphus Agricola]] (1444–1485), Latin name of German humanist Roelof Huysman. * [[Alchabitius]] (d.967) Latin name of astrologer Abu al-Saqr al-Qabisi. * [[Averroës]] (d.1198), Latin name of Ibn Rushd, Abu-i-Walid Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Muhammad, greatest Aristotelian philosopher of the Muslim world. * [[Avicenna]] (980–1037 CE) Latin name of Ibn Sina. * [[Comenius]] (1592–1670) Latin surname form of name of Czech religious reformer Jan Amos Komenský * [[Copernicus]] (1473–1543), astronomer – Latinised name, in his youth [[Niclas Koppernigk]]<ref>Dava Sobel A More Perfect Heaven: How Copernicus Revolutionised the Cosmos – Page 5 – 2011 "He was christened for his father — Mikolaj in Polish, Niklas in German, his native tongue. Later, as a scholar, he Latinized his name, but he grew up Niklas Koppernigk,"</ref> * [[Grotius]] (1583– ) Latin name of Dutch writer Hugh de Groot. * [[Flavius Josephus]] (37–93 or 100 CE) Latin name of Greek-language Jewish writer Joseph ben Matthias. * [[Samuel Maresius|Maresius]] (1599–1673) Latin surname of French Reformer Samuel Des Marets. * [[Gerardus Mercator|Mercator]] (1512–1594), Latin surname of Flemish cartographer Gheert Cremer. * [[Nostradamus]] (1503–1566) Latin surname of French seer Michel de Nostredame * [[Regiomontanus]] (1436–1476), Latin surname of German mathematician Johannes Müller von Königsberg * [[Salmasius]] (1588–1653), Latin surname of French classical scholar Claude Saumaise. * [[Michael Servetus]] (1511–1553), Latin name of Spanish non-trinitarian Miguel Servet. * Stephanus (1503–1559), Latin surname of French printer [[Robert Estienne]] first to print the Bible divided into standard numbered verses. * Stunica (d.1531), Latin surname of Spanish humanist [[Diego López de Zúñiga (theologian)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Exonyms]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} [[File:Location French West Africa.svg|thumb|French West Africa.]]
This is a list of European colonial administrators responsible for the territory of [[French West Africa]], an area equivalent to modern-day [[Mauritania]], [[Mali]], [[Niger]], [[Senegal]], [[Guinea]], [[Ivory Coast]], [[Burkina Faso]], [[Benin]] and [[Togo]].

page.title: List of flag bearers for Malta at the Olympics
List of islands of the Marshall Islands

revision.text:
[[File:MH -map A.png|thumb|400px|Islands and atolls of the Marshall Islands. Uninhabited ones are labeled in grey.]]
The '''Republic of [[Marshall Islands]]''' consists of 29 [[atoll]]s (each made up of many [[islet]]s) and 5 [[island]]s, which can be divided into two island chains, [[Ralik Chain]] and [[Ratak Chain]].
==Inhabited municipalities== Administratively, the country is divided into 24 inhabited [[municipalities]], corresponding to the 24 inhabited atolls or islands, where each of them is an [[electoral district]].
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Municipality ! Chain ! Population (1999) ! Area(km.²) ! Area(mi.²) |- | [[Ailinglaplap Atoll]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 1,959 || 15 || 6 |- | [[Ailuk Atoll]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 513 || 5 || 2 |- | [[Arno Atoll]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 2,069 || 13 || 5 |- | [[Aur Atoll]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 537 || 6 || 2 |- | [[Ebon Atoll]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 902 || 6 || 2 |- | [[Enewetak Atoll|Enewetok/Ujelang]] [1] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 853 || 6 || 2 |- | [[Jabat Island]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 95 || 1 || 0 |- | [[Jaluit Atoll]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 1,669 || 11 || 4 |- | [[Kili Island|Kili/Bikini/Ejit]] [2] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 1,062 || 1 || 0 |- | [[Kwajalein Atoll]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 10,902 || 16 || 6 |- | [[Lae Atoll]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 322 || 1 || 1 |- | [[Lib Island]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 147 || 1 || 0 |- | [[Likiep Atoll]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 527 || 10 || 4 |- | [[Majuro Atoll]] (capital) || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 23,401 || 10 || 4 |- | [[Maloelap Atoll]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 856 || 10 || 4 |- | [[Mejit Island]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 416 || 2 || 1 |- | [[Mili Atoll]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 1,032 || 16 || 6 |- | [[Namorik Atoll]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 772 || 3 || 1 |- | [[Namu Atoll]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 903 || 6 || 2 |- | [[Rongelap Atoll]] [3] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 19 || 8 || 3 |- | [[Ujae Atoll]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 440 || 2 || 1 |- | [[Utirik Atoll]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 433 || 2 || 1 |- | [[Wotho Atoll]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 145 || 4 || 2 |- | [[Wotje Atoll]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 866 || 8 || 3 |}
[http://www.nuclearclaimstribunal.com/177text.htm]
[http://bikiniatoll.wordpress.com/2012/01/23/new-kbe-mayor-nishma-jamore-and-local-government-council-members-take-oath-of-office/]
[3] Most of the Rongelapese community lives since 1985 on the Mejatto Island of Kwajalein Atoll, due to the [[radioactive contamination]] of their atoll.
==Uninhabited atolls/islands== The remaining 10 atolls/islands are currently uninhabited. According to the Constitution of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the uninhabited atolls/islands Narikrik, Erikub, Jemo, Taka, Bikar, Bokak, Rongrik and Ailinginae ''shall each be included in the electoral district with which it is most closely associated, pursuant to the customary law or any traditional practice.''<ref>[http://www.rmiembassyus.org/constitution/constitution.pdf Constitution of the Republic of the Marshall Islands] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122213801/http://www.rmiembassyus.org/Constitution/Constitution.pdf |date=2010-11-22 }}</ref> Ujelang is listed with the ''Enewetak & Ujelang District'', and Bikini with the ''Bikini & Kili District''.
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Atoll/Island !Chain !Area(km.²) !Area(mi.²) |- | [[Ailinginae Atoll]] [1] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 3 || 1 |- | [[Bikar Atoll]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 0 || 0 |- | [[Bikini Atoll]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 6 || 2 |- | [[Bokak Atoll]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 3 || 1 |- | [[Erikub Atoll]] [3] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 2 || 1 |- | [[Jemo Island]] [2] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 0 || 0 |- | [[Nadikdik Atoll]] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 1 || 0 |- | [[Rongerik Atoll]] [1] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 2 || 1 |- | [[Toke Atoll]] [4] || [[Ratak Chain|Ratak]] || 0.57 || 0.22 |- | [[Ujelang Atoll]] || [[Ralik Chain|Ralik]] || 2 || 1 |} *[1] Ailinginae Atoll and Rongerik Atoll traditionally belong to Rongelap Atoll [http://www.hss.doe.gov/Healthsafety/IHS/marshall/collection/ihp/chron/G51.PDF] *[2] Jemo Island belongs to the owners of Likiep Atoll (see there) *[3] Erikub Atoll belongs to the people of Wotja Atoll *[4] Toke Atoll belongs to the people of Utirik Atoll
==See also== *[[ISO 3166-2:MH]]

page.title: List of lifeboat disasters in Britain and Ireland

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} {{Incomplete list|date=September 2013}} [[File:Memorial sculpture - geograph.org.uk - 1619724.jpg|thumb|300px|The RNLI Memorial at Poole]] Many lives have been lost by [[Lifeboat (rescue)|lifeboat]] crews going to the aid of people and vessels in distress at sea and around the coasts of Britain and Ireland ([[UK]], [[Republic of Ireland]], [[Channel Islands]] and the [[Isle of Man]]), mainly but not exclusively in the service of the [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] (RNLI). More than 600 names are inscribed on the RNLI Memorial at RNLI HQ, Poole.{{cite web|title=The RNLI Heritage Trust preserves the history of the RNLI|url=http://rnli.org/aboutus/historyandheritage/Pages/Heritage-Trust.aspx|accessdate=5 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505165105/http://www.rnli.org/aboutus/historyandheritage/Pages/Heritage-Trust.aspx|archivedate=5 May 2014|df=dmy-all}} Some losses predate the RNLI (founded in 1824). ==19th century== In the 19th century, lifeboats were almost exclusively oar and sail powered. Self-righting boats had been developed but were not yet widely adopted. {| class="wikitable" |----- ! colspan="5" | British Isles lifeboat disasters in the 19th century |----- !style="text-align: center; background: |Date !style="text-align: center; background: |Lifeboat station !style="text-align: center; background: |Lifeboat crew lost !style="text-align: center; background: |Memorial !style="text-align: center; background: |Brief details and references |----- |1810||[[Hoylake]]||
8
|||| The men drowned when the lifeboat capsized in heavy seas while trying to aid the grounded ship ''Traveller''. |----- |1821||[[Sandycove]]||
4
|||| The men drowned while the lifeboat was assisting the brig ''Ellen of Liverpool''. |----- |1836||[[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]]||
10
|||| Lifeboat turned over by exceptional sea; four of the 14 crew survived. |----- |1859||{{Lbs|Aldeburgh}}||
3
|||| Lifeboat capsized in December with the loss of three of her 15 crew. |----- |1861||[[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]]||
2
|||| RNLI lifeboat ''Amelia'' wrecked on first service. Three members of the public who waded in also died, including Lord Charles Beauclerk. |----- |1866||[[Great Yarmouth and Gorleston Lifeboat Station|Gorleston]]||
12
||||The private lifeboat, ''Rescuer'', capsized in a storm with the loss of 12 of her crew.{{cite work|last=Higgins|first=David|date=1987|title=The Beachmen|publisher=Terence Dalton Limited|page=49-51|ISBN=0-86138-047-9}} It also deserves to be noted that a 13th fatality occurred when rescued crew member Robert Warner succumbed on 18 January 1866. This would appear to have been as a direct result of the disaster which took place on 13 January 1866.see: "The Late Life-boat Accident: The Norfolk News" 27 January 1866 |----- |1867||[[Great Yarmouth and Gorleston Lifeboat Station|Gorleston]]||
6
||[[File:Gorleston_lifeboat_memorial_1867.jpeg|75px]]||While returning to harbour after a rescue a fishing lugger collided with the private lifeboat, ''Rescuer''. She capsized and 6 of her crew and 19 other people drowned. |----- |1867||{{lbs|Padstow}}||
5
|| On the wall of St. Petroc's church, Padstow ||Lifeboat capsized during a service to the Georgiana |----- |1871||[[Bridlington]]||
6
|||| RNLI lifeboat ''Harbinger'' lost in the [[Great Gale of 1871]]. |----- |1874||[[Stonehaven]]||
4
||[[File:Memorial to the Stonehaven Lifeboat crew of 1874 - geograph.org.uk - 1378126.jpg|75px]]|| Four of the crew of the lifeboat ''St George'' drowned while trying to enter Aberdeen Harbour after going to assist ''Grace Darling'' of Blyth, which foundered between Stonehaven and Aberdeen. |----- |1877||{{Lbs|Aberystwyth}}||
1
||||John James, a member of the crew, died from exhaustion after a long service to a Schooner on 20 February. |----- |1880||{{Lbs|Wells-next-the-Sea}}||
11
||[[File:Shipwreck rescue memorial, Wells next the Sea - geograph.org.uk - 1049155.jpg|75px]]||[[Wells lifeboat disaster]]''Wells-next-the-Sea Lifeboats''. Author: Nicholas Leach & Paul Russell. Published by:Tempus Publishing Ltd, 2006. Work: Chapter 1.The first lifeboats at Wells – 1869 to 1888, page 14, Lifeboat Eliza Adams. {{ISBN|0 7524 3875 1}} 11 of the 13 crew of RNLI lifeboat ''Eliza Adams'' were lost when she capsized after an abortive attempt to go to the aid of the brig ''Ocean Queen'' in heavy seas. The crew of the brig survived. |----- |1883||{{Lbs|The Mumbles}}||
4
||||The lifeboat ''Wolverhampton'' was lost on service to the barque ''Admiral Prinz Adalbert of Danzig'' on 27 January; the tragedy was the inspiration for [[Clement Scott]]'s poem ''The Women of Mumbles Head''.{{cite web|title=Mumbles Lifeboat - History|url=http://www.mumbleslifeboat.org.uk/history.html|accessdate=9 May 2014}} |----- |1885||[[Caister Lifeboat|Caister]]||
8
|||| The yawl ''Zephyr'' struck a sunken wreck on a distress call to a schooner on the Barber Sands. Eight of the 15 crew were lost. |----- |1886||Southport||
14
||[[File:Southport lifeboat disaster memorial 1.JPG|75px]]|| 14 of the 16 crew of Southport's lifeboat ''Eliza Fernley'', and the whole crew of St Anne's lifeboat (see below) died while trying to aid the barque ''Mexico'' in heavy seas. It remains the worst lifeboat loss in history.
{{Main|Southport and St Anne's lifeboats disaster}} |----- |1886||[[Lytham St. Annes]]||
13
||[[File:Lytham memorial to RNLI lifeboat Laura Janet 1886.jpg|75px]]||The crew of the St Anne's lifeboat ''Laura Janet'', along with most of Southport's crew died in the same incident (see above). The crew of ''Mexico'' were rescued by Lytham's lifeboat.
{{Main|Southport and St Anne's lifeboats disaster}} |----- |1889||[[Portrush]]||
3
|||| Lifeboat ''The Robert and Agnes Blair'' went to the aid of the schooner ''Dryad'' and capsized off the coast off Portballintrae with the loss of three of the 13 crew. |----- |1895||[[Dún Laoghaire|Kingstown]]||
15
||[[File:Kingstown-1895-dis.JPG|75px]]||Kingstown's (now [[Dún Laoghaire]]) lifeboat ''Civil Service No. 7'' (ON 409) capsized while attempting to rescue the crew of the stricken ''SS Palme''. All 15 crew died.
{{Main|Kingstown Lifeboat Disaster}} |----- |1899||[[Aldeburgh]]||
7
|||| The lifeboat ''Aldeburgh'' capsized with the loss of seven of the 18 crew. |} ==20th century== During the 20th century many advances were made in safety and durability of lifeboats, including self-righting and motor power. Life jackets were continuously being improved. {| class="wikitable" |----- ! colspan="5" | British Isles lifeboat disasters in the 20th century |----- !style="text-align: center; background: |Date !style="text-align: center; background: |Lifeboat station !style="text-align: center; background: |Lifeboat crew lost !style="text-align: center; background: |Memorial !style="text-align: center; background: |Brief details and references |----- |----- |1900||{{Lbs|Padstow}}||
8
||||RNLB ''James Stevens No. 4'' (ON 421) |----- |1901||[[Caister Volunteer Lifeboat Service|Caister]]||
9
||[[File:Caister Lifeboat Disaster Memorial.jpg|75px]]||RNLB ''Beauchamp'' (ON 327) capsized in heavy seas during the "Great Storm" of 1901. Asked why they had persisted in their rescue attempts the retired coxswain was reported as saying "Caister men never turn back".
{{Main|1901 Caister lifeboat disaster}} |----- |1903||{{Lbs|The Mumbles}}||
6
||||RNLB ''James Stevens No. 12'' (ON 436) capsized while aiding the grounded Waterford steamer ''Christina'' near Port Talbot harbour. |----- |1907||{{Lbs|Ryde}}||
2
|||| On 1 January, the lifeboat ''Selina'' capsized in a squall while searching for a missing sailor, throwing the crew into the sea. The survivors were washed ashore with the lifeboat at Southsea. |----- |1908||[[Newquay]]||
1
|||| RNLB ''James Stevens No 5'' capsized. |----- |1910||{{Lbs|St Davids}}||
3
||||RNLB ''Gem'' (ON 59) was wrecked on [[The Bitches]] in Ramsey Sound near [[Ramsey Island]]. |----- |1914||[[Fethard-on-Sea|Fethard]]||
9
||||RNLB ''Helen Blake'' (ON 546) capsized and was totally wrecked on South Keeragh Island while going to the aid of the schooner ''Mexico''. |----- |1914||[[Peterhead]]||
3
||||RNLB ''Alexander Tulloch'' (ON 622), attempting to assist grounded Hull trawler ''Tom Tit'' in a storm, was wrecked.{{cite web|title=Peterhead Lifeboat Station - Geddes Plaque|url=http://www.peterheadlifeboat.co.uk/geddesplaque.htm|accessdate=9 May 2014}} |----- |1915||[[Bridlington]]||
1
|||| During a launch to the aid of the minesweeping trawler ''Lord Airedale'' (HMT No. 847), the carriage carrying the lifeboat collapsed, resulting in the death by drowning of horse driver Robert Carr. |----- |1915||[[Maritime history of Worthing|Worthing]]||
1
|||| While going to the aid of the schooner ''Kingshill'' the lifeboat capsized in rough seas.{{cite work|last=Elleray|first=D.R.|date=1998|title=A Millennium Encyclopaedia of Worthing History|publisher=Optimus Books|page=144|ISBN=0-9533132-0-4}}{{cite work|last=Hare|first=Chris|date=1991|title=Historic Worthing: The Untold Story|publisher=The Windrush Press|page=186-187|ISBN=0-900075-91-0}} |----- |1916||{{Lbs|Horton and Port Eynon}}||
3
||[[File:Coastguard memorial at Port Eynon - geograph.org.uk - 1315693.jpg|75px]]||The lifeboat ''Janet'', responding to a distress signal from the S.S. ''Dunvegan'', capsized twice in rough seas. |----- |1916||{{Lbs|Salcombe}}||
13
||||RNLB ''William and Emma'' (ON 524) capsized while going to the aid of the schooner ''Western Lass'', ashore beyond Prawle Point. |----- |1919||[[Fraserburgh]]||
2
||[[File:Lifeboat Memorial Statue - geograph.org.uk - 2026039.jpg|75px]]||RNLB ''Lady Rothes'' (ON 641) capsized while assisting H.M. Drifter ''Eminent''.{{cite news|title=Losses to Shipping and Property|newspaper=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=1919-04-29|page=7|issue=42086}}{{cite web|work=The Flag in the Wind |title=Notable Dates in History |publisher=''[[The Scots Independent]]'' |url=http://www.scotsindependent.org/dates1-g.htm |accessdate=2014-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140523225830/http://www.scotsindependent.org/dates1-g.htm |archivedate=23 May 2014 |df= }} |----- |1920||[[Rhoscolyn]]||
5
||[[File:Five lost lifeboat men and four graves - geograph.org.uk - 865486.jpg|75px]]||Crewmen lost in the attempt to rescue the crew of the SS ''Timbo'' in Caernarfon Bay |----- |1928||[[Rye Harbour]]||
17
||[[File:Lifeboat Memorial, Rye Harbour, East Sussex - geograph.org.uk - 272.jpg|75px]]||{{RNLB|Mary Stanford|ON 661}} capsized whilst coming into harbour after going to the aid of the Latvian steamer ''Alice of Riga''. |----- |1939||{{Lbs|St Ives}}||
7
||[[File:Memorial on the wall of St Ives lifeboat station - geograph.org.uk - 1548950.jpg|75px]]||RNLB ''John and Sara Eliza Styche'' (ON 743) capsized and self-righted three times, each time losing some of her crew. Only one crew member survived; the boat was wrecked. |----- |1939||[[Cullercoats]]||
6
||||RNLB ''Richard Silver Oliver'' (ON 794) was overwhelmed by a freak wave while training off Sharpness Point near Tynemouth Pier.{{cite web|title=Emotions run high at lifeboat memorial service|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/emotions-run-high-lifeboat-memorial-7020561|accessdate=8 May 2014}} |----- |1942||Newburgh||
2
|||| |----- |1947||{{Lbs|The Mumbles}}||
8
|| ||RNLB ''Edward, Prince of Wales'' (ON 678) capsized while trying to assist [[SS Samtampa|SS ''Samtampa'']] which had run aground and broken up at Sker Point during a storm. A total of 47 lives were lost.{{cite work|last=Porch|first=Richard|title=Swansea: History you can see|publisher=Tempus Publishing|date=2005|url=http://www.oystermouthparish.com/1947-mumbles-lifeboat-disaster|accessdate=8 May 2014}} {{main|The Mumbles Lifeboat disaster}} |----- |1951||[[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]]||
1
||||RNLB ''E.C.J.R.'' (ON 879). Whilst transferring from the casualty vessel to the lifeboat one crew member was trapped between the boats. |----- |1952||[[Bridlington]]||
1
||||RNLB ''Tillie Morrison, Sheffield'' (ON 851) capsized. |----- |1953||[[Fraserburgh]]||
6
||[[File:Lifeboat Memorial Statue - geograph.org.uk - 2026039.jpg|75px]]||RNLB ''John and Charles Kennedy'' (ON 790) capsized while escorting fishing vessels; one crew member survived. |----- |1953||[[Arbroath]]||
6
||||RNLB ''Robert Lindsay'' (ON 874) was sideswiped by a huge wave and flung on the rocks at Inchcape Park.{{cite web|title=Lifeboat disaster anniversary|url=http://www.arbroathherald.co.uk/news/local-news/lifeboat-disaster-anniversary-1-301078|publisher=Arbroath Herald|accessdate=17 September 2013}}{{cite news|publisher=HeraldScotland|title=Service marks lifeboat deaths 60 years ago|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/home-news/service-marks-lifeboat-deaths-60-years-ago.22530617|date=28 October 2013|accessdate=8 May 2014}} |----- |1954||[[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]]||
3
||||RNLB ''E.C.J.R.'' (ON 879) capsized near the harbour mouth. |----- |1959||[[Broughty Ferry]]||
8
||[[File:Mona Memorial, Broughty Ferry Lifeboat Station - geograph.org.uk - 1061720.jpg|75px]]||{{RNLB|Mona|ON 775}} capsized with the loss of the whole crew while attempting to rescue the crew of the North Carr Lightship. |----- |1962||[[Seaham]]||
5
||[[File:Seaham Lifeboat Memorial (2748044724).jpg|75px]]||RNLB ''George Elmy'' (ON 873) capsized yards from the harbour entrance after being struck by a wave, with the loss of the whole crew and four of the five people they had rescued from the coble ''Economy''.{{cite web |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1962/nov/20/seaham-harbour-lifeboat-loss |title=Seaham Harbour Lifeboat (Loss) |website=[[Hansard]] |date=20 November 1962 |accessdate=7 October 2016}} |----- |1969||[[Longhope, Orkney|Longhope]]||
8
||[[File:Longhope Lifeboat Memorial - geograph.org.uk - 1066362.jpg|75px]]||RNLB ''T.G.B.'' (ON 962) capsized in storm force seas when going to the aid of the ''Irene''. |----- |1970||Fraserburgh||
5
||[[File:Lifeboat Memorial Statue - geograph.org.uk - 2026039.jpg|75px]]||RNLB ''Duchess of Kent'' (ON 908) capsized after being struck by a wave more than 30ft high when assisting Danish fishing vessel ''Opal''; one crew member survived. |----- |1977||[[Kilmore Quay]]||
1
||||Oakley-class lifeboat RNLB ''Lady Murphy'' (ON 997) launched to red flares but found nothing; on their return they capsized twice.{{cite web|title=Kilmore-Quay Lifeboat - History|url=http://www.kilmorequaylifeboat.com/station%20history.html|accessdate=11 May 2014}} |----- |1981||{{Lbs|Penlee}}||
8
||[[File:Penlee lifeboat memorial.jpg|75px]]||RNLB ''Solomon Browne'' (ON 954) was lost with all hands while assisting MV ''Union Star'' in a severe storm; the five crew and three passengers from ''Union Star'' also died.
{{Main|Penlee lifeboat disaster}} |} ==See also== *[[Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] *[[List of RNLI stations]] *[[Independent lifeboats in Britain and Ireland]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Lifeboat wrecks and rescues |state=collapsed}} [[Category:Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] [[Category:Independent Lifeboat stations|*]] [[Category:Disasters in England]] [[Category:Disasters in Scotland]] [[Category:Disasters in Wales]] [[Category:Disasters in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Disasters in Ireland]] [[Category:British Isles-related lists|Lifeboat]] [[Category:Lists of disasters in Ireland]] [[Category:Lists of disasters in the United Kingdom]]

{{Infobox official post |post = Mayor |body = the
City of Sarajevo |native_name = Gradonačelnik Sarajeva |insignia = |insigniasize = 125px |insigniacaption = The Mayor’s chain of honour |department = |image = |imagesize = |alt = |incumbent = [[Abdulah Skaka]] |incumbentsince = 6 February 2017 |style = |residence = |nominator = |nominatorpost = |appointer = Sarajevo City Council |appointerpost = |termlength = 4 years, unlimited number of renewals |inaugural = [[Mustafa Fadilpašić]] |formation = 22 August 1878 |last = |end = |succession = |deputy = |salary = |website = [http://www.sarajevo.ba/ba/stream.php?kat=25 City of Sarajevo website] }} This is a list of people who have served as [[mayor]] or president of the [[city council]] of the city of [[Sarajevo]], the capital of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. Sarajevo has had 37 different mayors since the position was created on 22 August 1878, upon [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]] [[Austro-Hungarian campaign in Bosnia and Herzegovina in 1878|occupation]]. ==History== The first mayor of Sarajevo [[Mustafa Fadilpašić]] was also the city's longest-served mayor, having remained in the position for 14 years. The only mayor to serve more than once was [[Edhem Bičakčić]], who was mayor from 1928–29, then again from 1935–39. The first non-[[Bosniak]] mayor was [[Aristotel Petrović]] (1918–1920). [[Semiha Borovac]] became Sarajevo's first female mayor in 2005. [[Fehim Čurčić]], the city's fifth mayor, served during [[World War I]]. In 1941, Atih Hadžikadić was elected mayor, a position that was short-lived as he was hanged during [[World War II]] in August 1941. ==Mayors== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |-- ! # ! revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Use British English|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox islands | name = Channel Islands
{{native name|fr|Îles de la Manche}}
''Îles d'la Manche'' ([[Norman language|Norman]]) | native_name = | sobriquet = | image_name = Channel islands location.png | image_size = 239px | image_caption = Location of the Channel Islands | image_alt = | locator_map = | locator_map_size = | map_caption = | location = Western [[Europe]] | coordinates = | waterbody = [[English Channel]] | archipelago = | total_islands = 8 inhabited | major_islands = | area_km2 = | area_footnotes = | rank = | length_km = | length_footnotes = | width_km = | width_footnotes = | coastline_km = | coastline_footnotes = | elevation_m = | elevation_footnotes = | highest_mount = | country = {{flagdeco|Guernsey}} [[Guernsey|Bailiwick of Guernsey]] | country_admin_divisions_title = | country_admin_divisions = | country1 = {{flagdeco|Jersey}} [[Jersey|Bailiwick of Jersey]] | country1_admin_divisions_title = | country1_admin_divisions = | demonym = | population = | population_as_of = | density_km2 = | density_footnotes = | ethnic_groups = | website = | additional_info = }} The '''list of shipwrecks in the [[Channel Islands]]''' lists some of the [[ship]]s that wrecked on or sank in the waters of the [[Bailiwick of Guernsey]] and the [[Bailiwick of Jersey]]. The list includes ships that sustained a damaged hull, which were later refloated and repaired. There are at least 700 identified shipwrecks and another 100 unidentified, in Bailiwick of Guernsey waters alone.{{rp|105–128}} [[Jersey]] experiences some of the largest tidal ranges in the world, up to 12 metres;{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-26390204 |title=Channel Islands flooded after 'highest tide of the year'}} [[Guernsey]] has slightly less dramatic tides. The mass of water moving in and out gives rise to fast moving currents. Alderney has the [[Alderney Race]], which can run up to about twelve knots during equinoctial tides. These combined with the numerous smaller islands, offshore reefs, and isolated rocks extending up to {{convert|13|mi|km}} from the main islands, as well as the Islands' location close to the [[English Channel]] shipping channels, has resulted in thousands of shipwrecks over the centuries. [[File:Guernsey-Les Casquets.png|thumb|left|200px|Location map of Les Casquets]] The Bailiwick of Guernsey comprises the islands of [[Guernsey]], [[Alderney]], [[Sark]], [[Herm]] and a number of smaller islands, islets and rocks. See [[List of islands of the Bailiwick of Guernsey]] for a complete list of their smaller islands. [[Les Casquets]] or (The) '''Casquets''' ({{IPAc-en|k|æ|s|ˈ|k|ɛ|t|s}} {{respell|kas|KETS|'}}); is a group of [[islet|rock]]s 13 km west of [[Alderney]] and are part of an underwater [[sandstone]] ridge. Other parts which emerge above the water are the islets of [[Burhou]] and [[Ortac]]. Little vegetation grows on them. [[File:Jersey-Les Minquiers.png|thumb|left|200px]] The Bailiwick of Jersey comprises the island of [[Jersey]] and a number of smaller islets and rocks, most of which are covered at high tide. See [[List of islands of the Bailiwick of Jersey]] for a complete list of their smaller islands. [[Les Écréhous]] NE of [[Jersey]] consists of two reefs which form an extensive shoal area {{convert|7|mi|km}} long and {{convert|2.3|mi|km}} wide.[http://www.jersey.com/english/discoverjersey/sightseeing/Pages/Les-Ecrehous.aspx] [[Les Minquiers]] {{convert|9|mi|km}} S of [[Jersey]], its largest island is only 50 metres by 20 metres, but at low water, [[Les Minquiers]] has a land area greater than 100[[km²]]. The deliberate [[Wrecking (shipwreck)|wrecking]] of ships has not been a [[Channel Island]] trait, although the recovery of goods from a natural wreck has always been undertaken. [[Smuggling]] and [[Privateer]]'s{{cite web |url= http://www.priaulxlibrary.co.uk/articles/article/prizes |title=Prizes}} have abounded in the Islands' waters over many centuries. Modern navigation systems have helped reduce the number of disasters, but shipping still receive warnings of waters around the Channel Islands{{cite web |url=http://msi.nga.mil/MSISiteContent/StaticFiles/NAV_PUBS/SD/Pub191/Pub191bk.pdf |title=PUB. 191 SAILING DIRECTIONS (ENROUTE) ENGLISH CHANNEL |date=2014 |publisher=NATIONAL GEOSPATIAL-INTELLIGENCE AGENCY}} ==Key== {{legend2|#fcc|Jersey |border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|#dfffdf|Guernsey |border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|#ffffbf|Alderney |border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|#efcfff|Other |border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|#d0e7ff|Open sea |border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} ==12th to 19th centuries== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%; width:95%; border:0; text-align:left; line-height:150%;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:4%;" |Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:15%;" |Ship ! rowspan="2" style="width:15%;" | Flag ! rowspan="2" style="width:10%;" |Location ! rowspan="2" style="width:45%;" |Narrative ! rowspan="2" style="width:11%;" |Coordinates |- |- | 3rd Century | "Asterix" | unknown flag | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | St Peter Port harbor. It is thought to be a Roman cargo vessel and was probably at anchor or grounded when the fire broke out.{{cite web |url=http://museums.gov.gg/romanship |title=Gallo-Roman Ship}} | {{coord|49|27|19|N|2|31|35|W|name=Asterix}} |- | 1120 | '''''[[White Ship]]''''' | ({{flagicon|Normandy}}) [[Henry I of England|Henry I]] | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Les Casquets]] | In 1120, the ''White Ship'', carrying Prince William, son of [[Henry I of England]] with three hundred fellow passengers: 140 knights and 18 noblewomen; his half-brother, Richard; his half-sister, Matilda the Countess of Perche; his cousins, Matilda of Blois; the nephew of the German Emperor Henry V; the young Earl of Chester and most of the heirs to the great estates of England and Normandy, was being rowed back to England by a drunken crew when it hit the Casquets rocks and sank. There was only one survivor.{{cite web |url=http://www.britannia.com/history/bb1120.html |title=The Wreck of the White Ship}}{{cite book |title=The Annals of Europe, Or Regal Register; Shewing the Succession of the Sovereigns, ... Together with the Bishops and Popes of Rome, Etc |publisher=F. Newbery, 1779 |page=197}}{{cite book |first=John Brett |last=Edwin |title=Brett's Illustrated Naval History of Great Britain, from the Earliest Period to the Present Time: A Reliable Record of the Maritime Rise and Progress of England |publisher=Publishing Office, 1871 |page=25}} | |- | 1565 | '''John of Sandwich''' | Pirate | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | The ship was wrecked on the coast of Guernsey. The crew, confessing to be pirates, were imprisoned in [[Castle Cornet]] from which the commander and his officers escaped. One of the crew was hanged as an example.{{cite book |first=Ferdinand Brock |last=Tupper |title=The Chronicles of Castle Cornet |publisher=Stephen Barbet 1851}}{{rp|29}} | |- | 1592 | '''''Makeshift''''' | ({{flagicon|England}}) [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]] | style="background:#ffffbf;"| [[Alderney]] | Pinnace-yacht, sank off [[Alderney]] [[Channel Islands]]. Artifacts from this wreck is featured in the [[Alderney Museum]] and is managed by the Alderney Maritime Trust.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?83172 |title=Makeshift HMS? [+1592] |publisher=wrecksite.eu}}{{cite web |url=http://www.alderneywreck.com/index.php/the-wreck/historical-context |title=An Elizabethan shipwreck off the Island of Alderney |publisher=alderneywreck.com}} | {{coord|49|44|17|N|2|09|51|W|name=Makeshift}} |- |1666 | '''{{ship||La Vierge du Bon Port|East Indiaman|2}}''' | ({{flag|France}}) | style="background:#d0e7ff;"| Open Sea | The [[French East India Company]] ship was one of four sent to [[Colonization|colonise]] [[Merina Kingdom|Madagascar]]. She left for home on 20 February and within days of her destination of [[Le Havre]], she was attacked by an English [[Privateer|corsair]] and sank off [[Guernsey]] on 9 July 1666. At the time she was reported to be carrying a valuable cargo worth £1,500,000.{{cite web|last1=Allen|first1=Tony|title=La Vierge Du Bon Port (+1666)|url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?140136#121945|website=Wrecksite|accessdate=26 July 2014}}{{cite book |last=Seneuze |first=Arnoul |title=Memories pour servir a l'histoire des Indes Orientales |page=239 |year=1688 |publisher=M.S.D.R. |location=Paris}} | |- |1701 | '''Michael''' | unknown flag | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Les Casquets]] | The sailing vessel hit the Casquets rocks, several sailors managed to get ashore and sheltered in some huts. They were found just before they starved to death.{{cite book |last=Coysh |first=Victor |title=Maritime Alderney |publisher=Guernsey Press |ISBN=0902550438 |date=1991}}{{rp|19}} | |- | 1712 | '''{{HMS|Dragon|1647|6}}''' | ({{flagcountry|Kingdom of Great Britain|white}} [[Royal Navy]]) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Les Casquets]] | The [[fourth rate]] frigate was escorting a convoy from [[Guernsey]] to [[England]] when it was wrecked on [[Les Casquets]], west of [[Alderney]] with no recorded lives lost.{{cite web |url=https://sites.google.com/site/alderneylocalhistory/Home/1700s/1712-wreck-of-hms-dragon |title=1712 Wreck of HMS Dragon}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?83142 |title=HMS Dragon [+1711]}} | |- | 1721 | '''{{HMS|Hind|1711|2|}}''' | ({{flagicon|Kingdom of Great Britain|white}} [[Royal Navy]]): | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | 20-gun sixth rate launched in 1711 and wrecked in 1721. The ship struck a rock "half a musket shot" off [[Castle Cornet]] [[Guernsey]] on 7 December 1721, and 21 hands were lost including the [[Sea captain|Captain]] Fuzzard. The loss was attributed to the "ignorance of the [[Maritime pilot|pilot]]". 94 of the ship's company were saved.{{cite news |title=From the Whitehall Evening Post, Jan 2|work=Caledonian Mercury |date=9 January 1722 |accessdate=6 September 2014 |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000045/17220109/004/0003| publisher = [[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}} Amongst those rescued was the [[Ship's doctor|ship's surgeon]], Mr Forkington, "who was laid up with the [[gout]], but made shift to swim to a rock not far distant, and the cold baths that endangered his life, hath effectively cured his said distemper."{{cite news |title=From the Weekly Journal; Or, Saturday's Post, London Jan.6|work=Newcastle Courant |date=13 January 1722 |accessdate=6 September 2014 |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000085/17220113/013/0008| publisher = [[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}} The pilot was tried and found guilty, and was sentenced to three years imprisonment and loss of pay.{{cite news |title=From the St Jame's Evening Post, London Jan.18|work=Newcastle Courant |date=27 January 1722 |accessdate=6 September 2014 |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/BL/0000085/17220127/005/0003| publisher = [[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}} | |- | 1744 | '''{{HMS|Victory|1737|6}}''' | ({{flagicon|Kingdom of Great Britain|white}} [[Royal Navy]]) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Les Casquets]] | The [[first rate]] [[ship of the line]] foundered between the [[Channel Islands]] and the French coast with the loss of her crew of about 900 men.{{rp|14}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?460 |title=HMS Victory (+1744)|publisher=wrecksite.eu}}{{cite web |url=http://www.alderneywreck.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/08/amt-hms-victory-4-aug-2010.pdf |title=HMS "Victory" – The Alderney Maritime Trust’s Position |publisher=alderneywreck.com}} | {{coord|49|43|4|N|2|22|7|W|name=HMS Victory}}) |- | 1747 | '''''Cerf''''' | ({{flagcountry|France|naval}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Minquiers]] | Frigate constructed and based in [[Saint Malo]] (Brittany, France). Probably privateer. Sank in the mist at the [[Minquiers]] on 25 January 1747.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?210253 |title=SV Cerf (+1747) document |publisher=wrecksite.eu }} | |- | 1777 | '''{{HMS|Sprightly|1777|6}}''' | ({{navy|UK}}): | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | Shipwreck of new cutter of 12 guns 'Sprightly' capsized with loss of life, (Lt William Hills) off [[Les Hanois]] reef west of [[Guernsey]] [[Channel Islands]], whilst chasing a smuggler.{{rp|14}}{{cite web |url=http://www.worthpoint.com/worthopedia/1777-gold-guinea-ef-condition-hms-305067415 |title=1777 GOLD GUINEA IN EF CONDITION FROM HMS SPRIGHTLY SHIPWRECK}} | |- | 1779 |'''''Valentine''''' | ([[File:Flag of the British East India Company (1707).svg|22px]] [[British East India Company]]) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Brecqhou]] | The [[East Indiaman]] sailing from [[River Shannon|Shannon]] to [[London]] was lost off [[Brecqhou]], [[Channel Islands]] on 16 November 1779 in a gale.{{cite web |url=http://www.oceantreasures.org/pages/content/world-of-shipwrecks/a-short-list-of-english-east-indiamen-losses.html |title=Losses from the East India Company's ships (1763 - 1815) |publisher=Ocean Treasures |accessdate=17 January 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/fac/arts/history/ghcc/research/eicah/houses/valentinesmansion/shipwrecks/valentine_excavation_report_1976.pdf |title=Valentine |publisher=warwick.ac.uk }} | |- | 1795 | '''{{HMS|Amethyst|1793|6}}''' | ({{flagicon|Kingdom of Great Britain|white}} [[Royal Navy]]) | style="background:#ffffbf;"| [[Alderney]] | The 5th rate 38 gun [[Frigate]], originally the French "Perle" which was launched in 1790 and captured in 1793 hit the Hannouaux (Hanois) rocks off the coast of [[Alderney]] and was driven into [[Braye Harbour|Braye]] bay on 29 December 1795. The crew got ashore without loss, however two rescuers drowned.{{rp|14}}{{cite web |url=http://www.pbenyon.plus.com/18-1900/A/00228.html |title=Amethyst, Late Perle, 1793}}{{rp|22}} | |- | 1800 | '''HMS ''{{HMS|Pelican|1795|2}}''''' |({{flagicon|Kingdom of Great Britain|white}} [[Royal Navy]]) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]]
[[Saint Aubin, Jersey|St Aubin's Bay]] | The 18-gun ''Pelican'' was driven ashore and wrecked in St. Aubin's Bay on 9 November 1800 but later refloated.''Lloyd's List'',[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1800/11-14-1800.jpg] - accessed 20 December 2013.{{cite web |url=http://doug-jersey.freeservers.com/Havick%20-%20Who%20else%20was%20in%20the%20bay.htm |title=Who else was in the bay on 9 November 1800?}} | {{coord|49|11|N|2|09|W|name=HMS Pelican}} |- | 1800 | '''HMS [[Dutch sloop Havik (1784)|''Havick'']]''' | ({{flagicon|Kingdom of Great Britain|white}} [[Royal Navy]]) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]]
[[Saint Aubin, Jersey|St Aubin's Bay]] | The sloop foundered on 9 November 1800, settled into the sand, could not be re-floated and became a wreck.{{cite news |title=SHIP NEWS. |newspaper=Hull Packet |date=18 November 1800 |issue=696}}{{cite web |url=http://doug-jersey.freeservers.com/The%20wreck%20of%20HMS%20Havick%201800.htm |title=The wreck of HMS Havick 1800}} | {{coord|49|11|N|2|09|W|name=HMS Havick}} |- | 1801 | '''''Denton''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | The transport ship was wrecked on 9 February 1801.{{Cite news |title=Ship News |newspaper=The Morning Chronicle |date=16 February 1801 |issue=9903 }} | |- | 1801 | '''''Morning Star''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | The ship foundered in the [[English Channel]] off [[Guernsey]], in May 1801.{{Cite news |title=LLOYD's MARINE LIST - May 26. |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=30 May 1801 |issue=12436 }} | |- | 1801 | '''''Sukey''''' | ({{flag|United States|1795}}) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]] | wrecked at [[Jersey]].{{Cite news |title=LLOYD's MARINE LIST - April 17. |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=20 April 1801 |issue=12419 }} | |- | 1802 | '''''Hero''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | The ship was driven ashore and wrecked at while on a voyage from [[Naples]], [[Kingdom of Sicily]] to Guernsey{{Cite news |title=LLOYD's MARINE LIST - February 2. |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=6 February 1802 |issue=12544 }} | |- | 1802 | '''{{HMS|Pomone|1794|6}}''' | ({{navy|UK}}) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]]
[[Saint Aubin, Jersey|St Aubin's Bay]] | The [[frigate]] which had been captured from the French in 1794, struck a rock in [[Saint Aubin, Jersey|St Aubin's Bay]], [[Jersey]] and sank. On 23 September 1802. She was later refloated but was declared a [[constructive total loss]]. | {{coord|49|11|N|2|09|W|name=HMS Pomone}} |- | 1803 | '''{{HMS|Determinee|1799|6}}''' | ({{navy|UK}}) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]]
[[Saint Aubin, Jersey|St Aubin's Bay]] | The 6th rate [[Frigate]] stuck broadside on to a sunken rock near Noirmont Point on the western side of [[Saint Aubin, Jersey]] [[Channel Islands]] on 26 March 1803 where she was immediately bilged and started taking in water. 17 were lost including men, women and children from the [[81st Regiment of Foot (Loyal Lincoln Volunteers)]]{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?16629 |title=HMS Determinee [+1803] |publisher=wrecksite.eu}} | {{coord|49|11|N|2|09|W|name=HMS Determinee}} |- | 1803 | '''[[HMS Grappler (1797)|''Grappler'']] (ex ''GB No. 28'')''' | ({{navy|UK}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Chausey]] | En route from [[Guernsey]] to [[Granville, Manche|Granville]] on 23 December, the Courser class gun-brig sought shelter off the island of Maitre, one of the Iles [[Chausey]]. The storm abated on 30 December 1803, but on leaving the anchorage a hawser parted and ''Grappler'' drifted on to a half-tide rock, breaking in two as the tide dropped.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?16962 |title=HMS Grappler (+1803) |publisher=wrecksite.eu}} | |- | 1804 | '''''Harry''''' | ({{flagicon|UKGBI|civil}} [[Guernsey]]) | style="background:#ffffbf;"| [[Alderney]] | The ship was wrecked at [[Alderney]]{{Cite news |title=SHIPPING AND COMMERCIAL LIST. |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=19 April 1804 |issue=12889}} | |- | 1804 | '''''James and John''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]] | The ship was wrecked at [[Jersey]].{{Cite news |title=SHIPPING AND COMMERCIAL LIST. |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=2 April 1804 |issue=12882 }} | |- | 1804 | '''{{HMS|Severn|1786|6}}''' | ({{navy|UK}}) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]]
[[Grouville]] | The {{sclass-|Adventure|frigate}} was driven ashore and wrecked in [[Grouville]] bay, [[Jersey]] on 21 December 1804 in a gale. Her crew were rescued.{{Cite news |title=Ship News |newspaper=The Aberdeen Journal |date=2 January 1805 |issue=2973 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?17577 |title=HMS Severn (+1804)|publisher=wrecksite.eu }}{{cite book |first=Jane |last=Ashelford |title=In the English Service: The Life of Philippe D'Auvergne |publisher=Jersey Heritage Trust |ISBN=978-0955250880}}{{rp|113}} | |- | 1805 | '''''Adventure''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]] | Her crew were rescued. She was on a voyage from [[Malta]] to [[London]].{{Cite news |title=Ship News |newspaper= |date= 1806 |issue=Issue '''xxxx''' }} | |- | 1805 | '''''Fame''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | The [[privateer]] [[frigate]] was at anchor but was driven ashore and wrecked on Castle Rocks, [[Guernsey]] on 31 January 1805 in a storm that had also broken her mizzenmast. Her 150 crew were rescued.{{Cite news |title=Ship News |newspaper=The Aberdeen Journal |date=6 February 1805 |issue=2978 }} | |- | 1805 | '''''Pigmy''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]]
[[Saint Aubin, Jersey|St Aubin's Bay]] | Originally a French 14 gun Cutter Le MUTINE, renamed in 1797 when captured and renamed as [[HMS Mutine (1797)|HMS MUTINE]], but sold in 1803, the Pigmy was wrecked in [[Saint Aubin, Jersey|St Aubin's Bay]], [[Jersey]] on 9 August 1805. The pilot Nicholas de Leree had thought there was enough water to pass over a reef of rocks stretching from Sillet Point but she grounded and was bilged. Boats came to her assistance from ALCMENE, ALBICORE, CONQUEST and ECLIPSE and took her people off.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?17230 |title=HMS Mutine (ex-Le Mutin +1805) (+1805) |publisher=wrecksite.eu }}{{cite web |url=http://www.naval-history.net/xGM-Chrono-22MS-Algerine-HMS_Mutine.htm |title=HMS MUTINE (J 227) |publisher=naval-history.net}} | {{coord|49|11|N|2|09|W|name=Pigmy}} |- | 1806 | '''''Neptune''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#ffffbf;"| [[Alderney]] | The ship was wrecked on a voyage from [[Bristol]], [[Gloucestershire]] to [[Guernsey]].{{Cite news |title=LLOYD's SHIPPING LIST - Jan. 28. |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=1 February 1806 |issue=13115 }} | |- | 1807 | '''{{HMS|Boreas|1806|6}}''' | ({{navy|UK}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]]
Les Hanois | The 28-gun {{sclass-|Laurel|post ship}} struck rocks on [[Les Hanois]] reef SW of [[Guernsey]] and was wrecked with the loss of all but 47 of her 155 crew on 28 November 1807 when towing a pilot cutter to safety. Only two officers and 45 men were saved when Boreas went down immediately after striking the sunken rock leaving only the masts and rigging above sea level. Among those lost were Capt Robert SCOTT and his wife.{{rp|25}}{{cite web |url=http://www.priaulxlibrary.co.uk/articles/article/100-men-lost-hms-boreas-28-november-1807 |title=100 men lost: HMS ''Boreas'', 28 November 1807}} | |- | 1808 | '''''Active''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | The ship was wrecked on [[Guernsey]].{{Cite news |title=LLOYD's MARINE LIST - Feb. 19.1808 |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=22 February 1808 |issue=13442 }} | |- | 1812 | '''''Cynthia''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#ffffbf;"| [[Alderney]] | The ship was wrecked on the coast of [[Alderney]] on 23 February 1812{{Cite news |title=LLOYD's MARINE LIST - March 10. 1812 |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=14 March 1812 |issue=14077 }} | |- | 1812 | '''''Mars''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | The ship was wrecked on 9 April 1812. She was on a voyage from [[Guernsey]] to [[Plymouth, Devon]].{{Cite news |title=LLOYD's MARINE LIST - April 14, 1812. |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=18 April 1812 |issue=14092 }} | |- | 1814 | '''''Active''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#ffffbf;"| [[Alderney]] | The ship was wrecked with the loss of all hands.{{Cite news |title=Ship News |newspaper=The Hull Packet and Original Weekly Commercial, Literary and General Advertise |date=8 February 1814 |issue=1421 }} | |- | 1814 | '''''Pomona''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#d0e7ff;"| Open Sea | The ship departed [[Alderney]], Channel Islands for [[Guernsey]], on 14 November 1814. No further trace, presumed foundered in the [[English Channel]] with the loss of all hands.{{Cite news |title=LLOYD'S MARINE LIST - Dec. 13. 1814. |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=17 December 1814 |issue=14512 }} | |- | 1814 | '''''Arinus Marinus''''' | ({{flagicon|France}} [[First French Empire|French Empire]]) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]]
[[Gorey]] | The ship was driven ashore on 29 December 1814. She was on a voyage from [[Rotterdam]] to [[Jakarta|Batavia]].{{Cite news |title=LLOYD'S MARINE LIST - Jan. 3, 1814 |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=7 January 1815 |issue=14521 }} | |- | 1815 | '''''Leicester''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|government}}) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]] | The transport ship was driven onto a rock and was wrecked on 7 January 1815.{{Cite news |title=LLOYD'S MARINE LIST - Jan. 13, 1814[sic] |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=16 January 1815 |issue=14525 }} | |- | 1815 | '''''Bonne Annette''''' | ({{flag|France}}) | style="background:#d0e7ff;"| Open Sea | The ship foundered in the [[English Channel]] whilst on a voyage from [[Cherbourg]], [[Seine-Maritime]] to [[Guernsey]], on 25 April 1815.{{Cite news |title=LLOYD'S MARINE LIST - May 9. 1815. |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=13 May 1815 |issue=14575 }} | |- | 1815 | '''''Fanny''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Jethou]] | The ship struck a rock off [[Jethou]], Channel Islands and foundered. [[Bréhon Tower]] | The Alderney cutter ''Experiment'' was wrecked off [[Bréhon Tower]], between [[Guernsey]] and [[Herm]] in March 1850. The Captain and 8 passengers drowned but 20 were saved by the Guernsey pilot boat ''Mary of Guernsey''.{{cite book |first=Ray |last=Dafter |title=Guernsey Wrecks |ISBN=0-9540595-0-6 |publisher=Matfield Books}}{{rp|9}}{{cite book|last=Coysh|first=Victor|title=Channel Islets|year=1985|publisher=Guernsey Press|location=Guernsey|isbn=0902550128}}{{cite web |url=http://www.rnli.org.gg/lifeboat-timeline/lifeboat-timeline-1803-1899/ |title=1850 |publisher=RNLI}}{{cite web |url=http://collections.rmg.co.uk/collections/objects/140558.html |title=The Survivors of the Crew and Passengers of the Cutter Experiment |publisher=Royal Museums Greenwich}} | {{coord|49|28|N|2|30|W|name=Experiment}} |- | 1850 | '''{{ship||Polka|paddle steamer|2}}''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Minquiers]] | On a run from [[Saint Malo]] to [[Jersey]] as a replacement ship, the Paddle Steamer sprang a leak and began to sink near the [[Minquiers]] S of Jersey on 15 September 1850. All passengers and crew took to the lifeboats and were rescued. On 15 September 1850, the steam tug Polka was hurriedly pressed into service to make the daily run to St. Malo as Superb was undergoing repairs at St. Helier. When she was about halfway to her destination, Polka sprang a leak and began to sink whereupon her master, Captain Priaulx, calmly loaded everyone into the two lifeboats and landed them safely on the nearby Mâitre Ile. Picked up and taken into St. Malo the next day, the survivors counted themselves extremely fortunate and lavished both praise and a sizeable reward upon Captain Priaulx for his admirable seamanship.{{cite web |url=https://www.bonhams.com/auctions/10693/lot/79/ |title=Philip John Ouless (British, 1817-1885)}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?119256 |title =Polka [+1850] |publisher=wrecksite.eu}} | |- | 1850 | '''{{ship||Superb|paddle steamer|2}}''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Minquiers]] | The paddle steamer was running from [[Saint Malo]] to [[Jersey]] with 60 passengers, including survivors from the {{ship||Polka|paddle steamer|2}} ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) on approaching the [[Minquiers]] reef, they went to inspect where the PSS Polks had sunk, whereupon they themselves struck a rock, which caused panic and 20 people lost their lives, the rest being saved. On 17 September, only two days after the sinking of the PSS Polka, Superb left St. Malo with sixty passengers and crew aboard, including Captain Priaulx and several of the other survivors from the Polka. As they approached the Minquiers Reef, Superbs’ mate (John Fleming) was persuaded by some of the passengers to show them where the Polka had gone down but unfortunately, as he took Superb through the so-called eastern passage, she struck a rock known as La Pointue du Blanc Roc which tore deep into her hull. In the ensuing panic to load the lifeboats, twenty people lost their lives, four of whom had barely recovered from their experiences on the sinking Polka two days previously. Ironically, Superb herself remained stranded on the rock and the survivors including, once again, Captain Priaulx, were plucked straight off the decks by the rescue ships sent out from St. Helier. As an interesting postscript, one small vestige of Superb lived on after her boilers were salvaged and subsequently installed into one of her successors, another paddle steamer, the Rose, which took her name from Thomas Rose, the owner of the company. One of the earliest steamships operating in the waters around the Channel Islands, the Superb was owned by the Jersey Steam Packet Company of St. Helier which ran her on their scheduled Jersey to St. Malo [and Granville] mail and passenger service.{{cite web |url=https://www.bonhams.com/auctions/10693/lot/79/ |title =Philip John Ouless (British, 1817-1885)}}{{cite web |url=http://en.calameo.com/read/0008025524289752f2748 |title=Dictionnaire des naufrages dans la Manche |author=YvesDufiel}} | |- | 1857 | '''''Boadicea''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Les Casquets]] | The barque mistook the [[Les Casquets]] west of [[Alderney]] on 5 January 1857 for the Scillies. She was driven onto Tautenay rock in the Little Russel. The brig ‘Diolinda’ raised the alarm and steam tug ‘Watt’, H.M. Revenue Cutter ‘Eagle’ and Pilot boat ‘Blonde’ between them saved 6 of 15 crew. An RNLI silver medal was awarded to William Cockrom a steward on the 'Eagle'.{{cite web |url=http://www.rnli.org.gg/lifeboat-timeline/lifeboat-timeline-1803-1899/ |title=1857 |publisher=RNLI}} | |- | 1859 | '''''Express''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]]
La Corbière | The South Western Steam Co mail ship sank near [[La Corbière]] [[Jersey]] on 20 September 1859.{{cite news |title=Wreck of the Jersey Mail Steam Packet " Express " on the Grunes Houillieres on the South West Coast of Jersey |newspaper=London Illustrated News |date=1859}} | {{coord|49|10|N|2|14|W|name=Express}} |- | 1862 | '''''Globe''''' | ({{flag|Jersey}}): | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Guernsey]]
[[Les Hanois]] | A schooner-brig from Jersey en route to Boston in ballast returning to Jersey struck les Hanois on 6 April 1862 in appalling weather conditions, eventually sinking near L'Ancresse. The crew of seven landed from a small boat at Vazon.{{rp|67}} | |- | 1863 |'''{{ship||Paris|paddle steamer|2}}''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}): | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]]
St Helier | The paddle steamer Paris left St Malo 28 July 1863 with 24 passengers and 12 tons of cargo, chiefly butter and eggs. She was under charge of a Jersey pilot of considerable experience named De La Cour, the day was beautiful and the sea was as smooth as a mill pond. Shortly before 9am the steamer was observed just off Elizabeth Castle which, with the hermitage forms an outwork of rock a short distance from the entrance to Victoria Harbour, [[Jersey]]. The tide was just beginning to flow. the Captain (Hemmings) asked the pilot which passage he was going to take. The Sellette or the middle passage. The Pilot replied that he would take whichever passage the Captain chose to which the latter replied that it was not his province to interfere, adding that it was high time the pilot made up his mind. The Captain again warned the pilot of the danger which was now clearly apparent. This warning was scarcely off his lips when the vessel struck on a rock known as ´GRUNE VAUDIN´. The engines were stopped and set for astern. It was then the captain ordered the lifeboats to be lowered. Ten minutes after the vessel struck, she went down in 5 fathoms of water. The Paris was valued at £7000 and was not insured. The masts of the sunken vessel were clearly visible from the shore.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?82895#15728 | title =PSS Paris [+1863] |publisher=wrecksite.eu}} | {{coord|49|10|N|02|07|W|name=PSS Paris}} |- | 1864 | '''''Jean Goujon''''' | ({{flagcountry|France}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Écréhous]] | Sailing from [[Havana|Havanna]] bound for [[Le Havre]] with a cargo of sugar, in a storm, at night, the Captain mistook his position and steered south of the rocks he thought were the [[Les Casquets]]. They were in fact the [[Écréhous]] and in doing so he ran onto the rocks off [[Jersey]] on 3 May 1864. The crew was saved.{{cite web |url=http://doug-jersey.freeservers.com/images/Goujon%201864.htm |title=The Wreck of the Jean Goujon}} | |- | 1865 | '''''Carioca''''' | ({{flagcountry|France}}) | style="background:#ffffbf;"| [[Alderney]] | Struck the rocks under Hermitage Rock Battery in [[Alderney]] in late December 1865. Gunner James Moore of the Royal Artillery in Alderney rescued 17 men of the crew; he was later awarded an RNLI Silver Medal.{{cite web |url=http://www.priaulxlibrary.co.uk/articles/article/season-alderney |title=From The Ladies' Companion and Monthly Magazine, 1868}}{{Cite news |title=WRECKS of the _Carioca_, off Alderney |newspaper=The Times |date=24 October 1865 |page=11a }} | |- | 1866 | '''''Dinanais''''' | ({{flagcountry|France}}) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]]

The crew escaped with life boats.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?208853 |title =SV Blayais (+1867) |publisher=wrecksite.eu}} | |- | 1867 | '''''Edouard''''' | ({{flag|France}}): | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Minquiers]] | The sloop was lost by hitting a rock N of Plateau des [[Minquiers]], S of [[Jersey]] on 5 February 1867.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?213838 |title=SV Edouard (+1867) |publisher=wrecksite.eu}} | |- | 1872 | '''{{SV|Assomption||2|}}''' | ({{flag|France}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | Sloop built in [[Cherbourg]] belonging to an owner of this city, which was wrecked on the coast of [[Guernsey]] on 26 September 1872.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?207365 |title=SV Assomption (+1872) |publisher=wrecksite.eu }} | |- | 1872 | '''{{SS|Gosforth||2|}}''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Herm]] | On a voyage from [[Sark]] to [[Guernsey]] the , carrying the [[Seigneur of Sark]] struck a rock between [[Herm]] and [[Jethou]] and sank. All crew and passengers got ashore on Herm{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/docBrowser.aspx?2034?5?1 |title=Gosforth SS (+1872) document |publisher=wrecksite.eu}} | {{coord|49|27|40|N|02|27|30|W|name= SS Gosforth}} |- | 1873 | '''{{ship||Waverley|paddle steamer|2}}''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | Two funnels, two masts side paddle wheel propulsion and accommodation for 450-560 passengers. Belgrave Bay | The Swedish wooden barque ELLA, built in 1851, on voyage from [[Gothenburg]] to [[Liverpool]] with a cargo of pit props, was lost after running aground in Belgrave Bay (Belle Grève), [[Guernsey]] on 11 January 1887. All managed to climb to the top of the cliffs safely apart from one elderly man who slipped and fell to his death.{{cite book |first=Ray |last=Dafter |title=Guernsey wrecks |ISBN=0-9540595-0-6 |publisher=Matfield Books |page=106}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?82956 |title=SV Ambassadrice [+1895] }} | |- | 1896 | '''''Marie Fanny''''' | ({{flagcountry|France}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Burhou]] | The French steamer struck rocks near Burhu, 14 died.{{rp|24}} | |- | 1898 | '''''Channel Queen''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | steaming from [[Plymouth]] to the [[Channel Islands]] was wrecked in bad weather and fog on the Black Rock, 1.5NM off [[Guernsey]]. Stella Disaster |publisher=akesimpkin.org}} | {{coord|49|43|7|N|02|23|27|W|name=Stella}} |- | 1899 | '''''Belgique''''' | unknown flag | style="background:#d0e7ff;"| Open Sea | Formerly called Mount Hebron, she foundered 6 nm NW of the [[Casquets]]{{cite web |url=http://www.flotilla-australia.com/iss.htm |title=MOUNT HEBRON}} | |- |} ==20th and 21st centuries== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%; width:95%; border:0; text-align:left; line-height:150%;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:4%;" |Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:15%;" |Ship ! rowspan="2" style="width:15%;" | Flag ! rowspan="2" style="width:10%;" |Location ! rowspan="2" style="width:45%;" |Narrative ! rowspan="2" style="width:11%;" |Coordinates |- |- | 1900 | ‘’’{{SS|Ibex||2|}}’’’ | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | The mail boat hit the Platte Fougere reef on 5 January 1900 in bad visibility. Two fatalities.{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsoll.org/resources/SCCLibraries/WreckReports/17739.asp |title=Wreck Report for 'Ibex', 1900 |publisher=plimsoll.org}} The ship was raised in July 1900 and returned to service. | |- | 1900 | '''''Antoinette''''' | ({{flagcountry|France}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | The Dundee class yacht, en route from Saint-Cast-Le-Guildo (Brittany, France) to [[Denmark]] loaded with wheat, was lost on 22 August 1900 with all hands S of [[Guernsey]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?2572 |title=Antoinette (+1900) |publisher=wrecksite.eu}} | {{coord|49|23|00|N|02|31|00|W|name=Antoinette}} |- | 1900 | ''{{SS|Hermann Köppen||2|}}''' | ({{flagcountry|Germany}}) | style="background:#ffffbf;"| [[Alderney]] | Ran aground on the rocks Barsier, west of [[Alderney]] on 5 March 1900 and was wrecked.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?201396 |title=SS Hermann Köppen (+1900) |publisher=wrecksite.eu}} | |- | 1900 | '''''Rossgull''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#fcc;"| [[Jersey]]
[[La Corbière]] | The ship on a voyage from [[Plymouth]] to [[Jersey]] ran aground on 4 December at night off [[La Corbière]], [[Jersey]] in a gale. 11 were saved but 9 men in one lifeboat drowned{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/docBrowser.aspx?1867?5?1 |title= Rossgull SS (+1900) document |publisher=www.wrecksite.eu}}{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article12822445 |title=The wreck of the Rossgull |work=The Mercury|location=Hobart, Tas.}} | {{coord|49|10|N|2|14|W|name=Rossgull}} |- | 1901 | '''{{HMS|Viper|1899|6}}''' | ({{navy|UK}}) | style="background:#ffffbf;"| [[Alderney]] | The {{sclass-|Viper|destroyer}} launched on 8 September 1899, this ship was the first turbine powered destroyer. Foundered on ´le Renonquet´ Reef off [[Alderney]] on 3 August 1901 during naval manoeuvers. Capable of 37 knots, she struck doing 22 knots, capsized and broke in two. All survived. Blown up by Navy to stop turbine secrets being leaked out.{{rp|64}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?462 |title=HMS Viper [+1901] |publisher=wrecksite.eu}}{{cite web |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=PBH19010916.2.44 |title=HMS Viper wrecked |work=Poverty Bay Herald|volume=XXVIII|issue=9253|date=16 September 1901|page=4}} {{rp|25}} | {{coord|49|44|14|N|02|16|32|W|name=HMS Viper}} |- | 1902 | '''''Liverpool''''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#ffffbf;"| [[Alderney]] | The iron four-masted sailing ship, the largest in the world at the time, was en route from [[Antwerp]] to [[San Francisco]] with general cargo when she sailed slowly onto the rocks at Hommeaux Florains, on the northeastern tip of [[Alderney]] on 25 February 1902 in fog. There was no loss of life.{{rp|71}}{{cite web |url=http://www.clydesite.co.uk/clydebuilt/viewship.asp?id=17568 |title=sv Liverpool}}{{cite web |url=http://www.judnick.com/judnick/ShipwrecksNearAlderney.htm |title=Shipwrecks near Alderney |author=John Elsbury}} Accessible via a causeway the people of Alderney "helped" recover the cargo.{{rp|26}} | |- | 1903 | '''{{SS|Nord||2}}''' | ({{flag|France}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Burhou]] | Ran aground and was wrecked on [[Burhou]] Island off [[Alderney]] on 29 May 1903 on a voyage from [[Boulogne]] to [[Bayonne]] with general cargo.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?200413 |title=SS Nord (+1903) |publisher=wrecksite.eu}} | |- | 1904 | '''{{ship||Fauvette|schooner|2}}''' | ({{flagicon|France}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Chausey]] | The schooner sank just north of the [[Chausey]] Islands on 7 January 1904. | |- | 1904 |'''{{ship||Noord||2}}''' | ({{flagcountry|Netherlands}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Burhou]] | wrecked on 25 September 1904 SE of [[Burhou]] [[Alderney]] [[Channel Islands]] | |- | 1904 | '''Dunsinane''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]]
St Sampson’s | The two masted ship, carrying granite, set sail at 7pm and ran into strong tides, forcing it onto the Black Rock outside St Sampsons' harbour [[Guernsey]]. The next few days the planking was removed from the hull and the cargo removed into waiting carts.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?2646 |title=SV Dunsinane [+1904] |publisher=wrecksite.eu}}{{cite web |url=http://guernseypress.com/news/2005/09/07/it-all-began-with-a-shipwreck/ |title=It all began with a shipwreck |publisher=Guernsey Press}}{{cite web |url=http://guernseymuseumsgalleries.e-printphoto.co.uk/view/29014281/mc07475_jpg |title=glass negative of the wreck of the 'Dunsinane' |publisher=guernseymuseums}} | {{coord|49|27|00|N|02|40|00|W|name=Dunsinane}} |- | 1906 | '''{{SS|Ocean Queen||2}}''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#dfffdf;"| [[Guernsey]] | Wrecked on south coast of [[Guernsey]] on 2 March 1906. Sailing from [[London]] to [[Jersey]] with cement and general.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?2768 |title=SS Ocean Queen [+1906] |publisher=wrecksite.eu}}{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsoll.org/resources/SCCLibraries/WreckReports2002/18903.asp |title=Wreck Report for 'Ocean Queen', 1906}} | {{coord|49|25|20|N|02|39|20|W|name=Ocean Queen}} |- | 1906 | '''{{SS|Courier II||2}}''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}); | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Jethou]] | The ship struck Les Anons a rock south of [[Jethou]] on 30 April 1906.Guernseythrough the lens, including Alderney, Sark, Herm and Jethou: photographs taken before 1914 Victor Coysh, Carel Toms, 1978 There were 29 survivors and 10 deaths. The ship was salvaged on 1 August 1906 and returned to service after repairs.http://www.thisisguernsey.com/2006/08/07/a-story-of-survival/ | {{coord|49|27|30|N|02|28|00|W|name= SS Courier}} |- | 1906 | '''{{SS|Leros||2}}''' | ({{flagcountry|Germany}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Burhou]] | En route from [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]] to [[Lisbon]] with a 240-ton cargo of Singer sewing machines when she ran aground in thick fog on Tasse de la Frette Rocks, NW [[Burhou]] near [[Alderney]] on 29 May 1906. The crew initially refused help, threatening to shoot the rescuers. The wreck was looted, resulting in Singer stopping production of that model as no spare parts would be available.{{rp|75}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?10715 |title=SS Leros (+1906)}}{{cite web |url=http://www.judnick.com/judnick/ShipwrecksNearAlderney.htm |title=Shipwrecks near Alderney}} | |- | 1906 | '''{{SS|Forth||2}}''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Herm]] | Ran aground in thick fog and was wrecked on Long Pierre Rock off [[Herm]], on 7 August 1906, whilst on passage from [[Middlesbrough]] to [[Saint-Malo]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?2668 |title=SS Forth [+1906] |publisher=wrecksite.eu}}{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsoll.org/resources/SCCLibraries/WreckReports2002/19014.asp |title=Wreck Report for 'Forth', 1906}} | |- | 1908 | '''{{SS|Rosella||2|}}''' | ({{flagcountry|UKGBI|civil}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Roches-Douvres Light|Roches Douvres]] | The ship was on a voyage from [[Penarth]] to [[Granville, Manche|Granville]] carrying a cargo of coal, when she was wrecked at [[Roches-Douvres Light|Roches Douvres]] Rocks, {{convert|15|mi|km}} from La Corbière, [[Jersey]] on 16 September 1908.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?175154 |title=SS Rosella (+1908) |publisher=wrecksite.eu}}{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsoll.org/resources/SCCLibraries/WreckReports2002/19526.asp |title=Wreck Report for 'Rosella', 1908}} | |- | 1908 | '''''France''''' | ({{flag|France}}): | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Minquiers]] | The cargo schonner that foundered on 15 November 1908 on the [[Minquiers]] S of [[Jersey]] when en route from [[Dunkirk]] for Granville with a cargo of Scoria.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?238013 |title=SV France (+1908) |publisher=wrecksite.eu}} | |- | 1909 | '''{{SS|Mjølner||2}}''' | ({{Flagcountry|Norway}}) | style="background:#efcfff;"| [[Burhou]] | The cargo ship was on a voyage from N.
